Furthermore, we expect to find objects at the 900 m/s range, which is the proposed escape velocity of the progenitor based on estimates of its mass. It was originally proposed that Haumea' s orbital elements previously resembled those of its family, but evolved to their current values. In this project we explore Kuiper Belt Objects at up to the 1 km/s dispersion velocity and examine their colors through B and I filters to determine if they a re associated with Haumea. A refined velocity distribution gives insight to the composition of the progenitor. Investigation of Antiferromagnetic YMnO 3 Using RA -SHG at 2.45eV Preston Zhou Mentors: David Hsieh and Alberto de la Torre YMnO 3 has a highly frustrated spin configurarion above TN = 70K. Below the neel temperature YMnO 3 freezes into an antiferromagnetic order not yet fully understood. Here, we utilize RA -SHG (Rotation anisotropy second harmonic generation), which is a form of meas urement that is extremely sensitive to inversion breaking phases of matter, including antiferromagnetism, to fully resolve the spin configuration in YMnO 3 . Previous SHG measurements show a maximal sensitivity to the antiferromagnetic order with 2.45 eV li ght. However, prior to this work, the Hsieh lab lack the capability to perform RA -SHG measurements at this photon energy. Thus, we developed an extension of the previous RA -SHG setup to 2.45 investigate the properties of YMnO 3 with the best experimental co nditions. Interaction B etween Cardiolipin and Two Mitochondrial Proteins, Mentor: David C. Chan OPA1 and Drp1 are proteins central for mitochondrial fusion and fission, respectively. Cardiolipin, a kind of mitochondrion- specific lipid, plays a key role in mitochondrial fisson and fusion. To figure out the binding of these two proteins and cardiolipin, a protein- lipid overlay assay was performed. I have been optimizing the assay by changing different conditions and got positive results using purified full length Drp1 and shortened versions of OPA1 . After that, I tested the Q785R mutant of OPA1, which has been shown to be defective for lipid binding. The results showed that its cardiolipin binding ability was not influenced negative ly. As a consequence, I have predicted other mutants that may lead to deficiency and purified them. Liposome floatation assay should be done in the future to quantify their binding. In order to figure out which domain of OPA1 is responsible for cardiolipin binding, 96 we noted that OPA1 has a region similar to dynamin's pleckstrin homology domain which is known to bind lipid. I found that this domain can bind cardiolipin, which triggered our interests to solve its structure. So far, we have got the initial cry stals of pH domain and are trying to optimize it. WAVE Undergraduate Research Fellowships W A V E WAVE 99 Creation of T ransgenic Caulerpa for Cytoskeletal S tudy Alfredo Arroyo Mentors: Elliot Meyerowitz and William T. Gibson Despite growing up to a meter in linear dimension and having the morphological equivalents of roots, stems, and leaves, Caulerpa is a giant, unicellular organism. To understand how this organism carries out complex development in the absence of multicellularity , we are attempting to create transgenic Caulerpa to examine cytoskeletal proteins and other cellular structures and mechanisms. To create transgenic Caulerpa , DNA constructs were built using two methods, Gibson assembly and a classical cloning method. The constructs consisted of histone and tubulin promoters and terminators with an mCherry fluorescent protein within a PBR -9 backbon e. Colonies grown with a Gibson assembled construct showed signs of cellular stress, grew in single colonies, and were very small. The classical cloning method has allowed us to build the individual parts of the final construct, which can then be ligated t ogether. We are currently trying to optimize Gibson assembly and classically assembling a DNA construct using a TOPO cloning approach. Future work will involve using particle biolistic techniques, injection, and agrobacterium to insert the construct into Caulerpa . Successful insertion of the constructs will allow for further elucidation of Caulerpa cellular mechanisms. Design and Implementation of a Spinal Cord Injury Rehabilitation Home Therapy Robot Aakash Bajpai Mentors: Joel Bur dick and Richard Chen The spinal cord is an essential electrochemical mechanical system in vertebrates. Affliction to this system can carry large physical, social, and financial burdens for people worldwide . Previous work has made great progress with the spinal stimulation, where an electrode is inserted in the lumbosacral region and stimulated. These therapies have shown promise when accompanied by physical the rapy in a hospital environment. Due to difficulties in transport, ease of use, and desire for comfort; a stand frame for home training use is preferable. Additionally evidence shows the central nervous sys tem is likely to encode complex motor activity into low -dimensional units called muscle synergies. To investigate this, perturbations will be imposed on the patient to excite and find these supposed synergies. This study proposes a home rehabilitation system for stand training. It is designed to have integrated sensors, a low -profile tilting mechanism, and a small footprint to fit within patient's homes. Designing a FRET Assay to Quantitatively Measure Elongation Arrest A ctivity of SRP9/14 Laura Briggs Mentors: Shu- ou Shan and Sowmya Chandrasekar Mammalian signal recognition particle (SRP) is a complex molecular machine that co -translationally localizes nascent proteins to cellular membranes. SRP9/14, one domain of mammalian SRP, arrests elongation of the nascent protein by binding the ribosome near the P site and competing directly with elongation factors. This project designs a Forster resonance energy transfer (FR ET) assay to measure this elongation arrest activity by fluorescently labeling both SRP9/14 and messenger RNA. We have identified, purified, and labeled several mutant proteins at different positions with proximity to the ribosome to test their ability to measure elongation arrest with FRET. The future of the project will focus on labeling messenger RNA, assembling SRP with these fluorescently - labeled residues, and then performing FRET. Once the assay is fully developed, we will be able to answer questions about the frequency of this elongation arrest activity, as well as its specificity to substrates that are eventually targeted by SRP. Synthesis and Characterization of Fluorous Bottlebrush Block Copolymers Using Ring Opening Metathesis Polymerization Mentors: Robert Grubbs and William Wolf Bottlebrush polymers are an interesting class of macromolecule that consist of a polymer backbone that is highly substituted with shorter polymer sidechains. Ring Opening Metathesis Polymerization (RO MP) is used to synthesize bottlebrush copolymers that can potentially self -assemble into photonic crystals. The use of fluorous macromonomers for ROMP has been observed in creating bottlebrush polymers that exhibit unique phase separation and aid in rapid self-assembly of 1D photonic crystals. Currently, we are investigating the synthesis of fluorous macromonomers and their use in the synthesis of bottlebrush block copolymers. Creation of XTEN -Based Mentors: David Tirrell Baccile A material called artificial protein hydrogels (APHs) could potentially be used to create more of a biologically accurate physical scaffold or e xtracellular matrix (ECM) replacement. Since humans are unable to reg enerate damaged tissue (with an exception of the liver and skin), this project can help tissue engineering aims of creating 100 more effective treatment strategies for tissue repair or r eplacement . Creating XTEN -based proteins for the APHs allows the proteins to be produced in E.Coli , be less immunogenic, and biodegradable. The XTEN proteins were assembled through a cloning technique called recursive ligation. The proteins are then expressed, purified through a nickle -nitrilotriacetic acid column (Ni-NTA), lyop hilized, electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and chemically crosslinked. The crosslinked proteins are made into the hydrogels and analyzed through rheology . The sequencing of the proteins confirmed the cloning of the proteins were successful. Through the SDS PAGE analysis, the proteins of interest appeared in the lane with the elutions and not in the flowthrough meaning the proteins were successfully express ed and purified. After lyophilizing, about 40 mg of the proteins were collected. These proteins will be created intro hydrogels and its bulk properties will be analyzed to determine deformation and flow behavior. Bioprinting of Tobacco BY -2 Cells for Dev elopment of Artificial Wood Sebastian Hendrickx -Rodriguez Mentors: Chiara Daraio and Eleftheria Roume li Artificial wood fabrication is a new research field currently being pioneered by Professor Daraio's research group at Caltech. Her team has developed a method to fabricate artificial wood solely from undifferentiated BY -2 tobacco cells by employing a controlled dehydration process that relies heavily on the use of molds, thereby limiting the final shape of the synthetic wood. To provide more creative and functional freedom on the ultimate form and composition of the material, my project focused on installing a 3D printer and creating a viable plant cell bioink. This broadens the range of applications for the generated wood to include: aesthetic improveme nt of ornamental plants such as bonsai, lab -grown wood blocks for construction, and bioprinting of in vitro tissues onto in vivo plants for healing of damage caused by disease or insects. However, contrary to mammalian cell bioprinting, plant cell bioprinting is still in its most nascent phase and plant cell bioinks do not work well with the micronozzles of traditional 3D printers. Therefore, a new pen had to be employed. This involved the design and creation of a circuit that allows communication between the digital output of the printer and the input of the new pen. In parallel, we developed a printable plant bioink on which the cells can live and grow, maturing until their eventual controlled death by dehydration. The combination of these two synergistic advancements laid the groundwork for printing a plant cell bioink on which cells can grow and prosper for the development and manufacturing of artificial wood. Two-Photon fluorescence imaging modality that utilizes multiple photons in order to excite a fluorescent molecule. Two -photon fluorescence microscopy has revolutionized scientific fields such as neuroscience because its low energy laser pulses allow for less cell damage and can therefore be used for live cell imaging. In this work, we present preliminary results for a neural implant that employs a dielectric metasurface doublet for two -photon excitation microscopy in order to observe the action potentials across optogenetically engineered neurons. Dielectric metasurfaces are two dimensional arrays of silicon nano -scatterers th at have the ability to change the behavior of light similar to conventional optical devices such as lenses. The objective of a two - photon microscope was replaced with a metasurface doublet in order to observe fluorescent materials using an 850nm light sour ce. Data Assimilation Morgan R. Maysam Shamai The Data Assimilation F acility seeks to create a hybrid experimental -computational system co nsisting of a water tunnel, a Captive Trajectory System (CTS), and a High Performance Computing Cluster (HPCC) for studying free - response hydrodynamic behavior of objects . One focus of the project is to design an online interface for visualizing the physical data (forces, ob ject velocity, p osition, etc.) from the CTS in rea l-time. Current progress includes extensive collaboration to create a template program which combines a prescribed trajectory program with a client- server data transf er program. Continuing the work includes integrating a visual charting library into the te mplate program for data visualization and then incorporating the program's data -transfer and visual elements into the captive trajectory program. The aforementioned data from a captive trajectory will be analyzed and compared to the free-response of an air foil in the wake of a cylinder with vortex shedding in order to validate the use of the CTS to replicate free -response dynamics. The Generation of the Distant Kuiper Belt by Planet Nine From a n Initially Broad Perihelion Distribution Tali Khain Mentors: Konstantin Batygin and Michael E. Brown The formation of the hypothesized Planet Nine, a distant and eccentric perturber, has recently been widely discussed in the literature. The various proposed mechanisms for its formation would have had distinct effec ts on the structure of the outer Solar System, potentially sculpting different incarnations of the Kuiper Belt. In this work, 101 we consider two initially uniform distributions of a synthetic Kuiper Belt, one with perihelion distance [30,36] AU (the "narro w" distribution) and one with [30,300 ] AU (the "broad" distribution). By running numerical simulations of these test particles in the presence of a nominal Planet Nine and the known Solar System, we are able to characterize the evolution of each of thes e populations. Interestingly, we find that the final q-distribution of the initially widely distributed Kuiper Belt exhibits a bimodal structure, with the lower -q peak corresponding to the objects anti -aligned to Planet Nine, and the higher -q peak correspo nding to the aligned objects. The final q- distribution of the narrow Kuiper Belt, however, only shows the lower anti -aligned peak, as the initially lower -q aligned objects migrate into the Planet Nine collisional domain and are subsequently ejected from the Solar System. The final distribution of aligned objects, then, is the distinguishing feature of these two Kuiper Belt populations. As a result, future observations of additional aligned objects will allow us to determine the initial structure of the Kuiper Belt, and in turn, point to the mechanism of Planet Nine's formation. Synthesis and Reactivity of a 9,10 -Anthracenyl Theodor Agapie Ligands have been shown to influence electronic and steric properties of a coordinated metal ion, allowing control of some of its physical and chemical properties. C -C coupling, small molecule activation, and cycloadditions have been observed using low -valent transition metals s upported by non -innocent ligands. The group non- ligands. extended pi-system such as anthracene and naphthalene has been of particular interest for the group. B ased on precedent from Kawaguchi et. al where a p -terphenoxide supported zirconium complex was reduced to activate small molecules , we envisaged a zirconium metal complex with a central anthracene moiety that will allow a more accessible oxidation states . The guiding hypothesis for this work is that the anthracene linker allow for more facile reductive elimination of redox non- the reduced Zr Zr(IV). Herein, reactivity of the -supported zirconium complex was further explored with regards to photo -induced reductive elimination and small molecule a ctivation. Leveraging Bulk Expression Data to Improve Single -Cell Rebekah Loving Mentor: Lior Pachter Recently developed sequencing -based technologies have allowed for unprecedented probing of cells to study disease, gene regulation, and biological evolution. An important instance is RNA -Seq, which leverages high- throughput sequencing to allow for expression analysis of single -cells. However the technology is fraught with biases, including low counts for transcripts resulti ng from dropouts, and quantification can be difficult due to significant noise. This leads to analysis challenges that are addressed with statistical methods. We develop and implement an Expectation- Maximization method for the joint analysis of single cell and bulk RNA -seq data, and incorporate it in the existing RNA -seq analysis software kallisto. The latent variables of our Expectation- Maximization algorithm are the estimated transcript abundance counts for each individual cell with the bulk estimated tra nscription abundance counts being the average across all cells. We write a combined likelihood of the single cell and bulk RNA -seq data, which reallocates the bulk RNA -seq data to the single cells, weighting the bulk data according to relative ratios of co unts. We run parallel quantification of single cell and bulk transcript abundances which, according to the likelihood function, become interdependent on each other. This technique provides higher resolution in quantification of single cell expression level s than current standards and provides quantitative insight into the bias of different library preparations of cell samples. We will further improve our method by clustering of bulk data and single cells prior to analysis which further increase accuracy. Synthesis of Cylindrocyclophane Scaffold Utilizing an Asymmetric Reductive Cross -Coupling Reaction asymmetric reductive cross- electrophile coupling reactions as a method to forge C -C bonds is of significant interest to the synthetic community. Reductive cross -coupling reactions offer several advantages over more traditional organometallic reagents by expanding functional group tolerance and allowing for a mor e direct synthesis. In an effort to highlight the synthetic utility of these reactions, we aim to synthesize a unique class of natural products, cylindrocyclophanes through the use of the asymmetric reductive cross- coupling reaction of vinyl bromides and b enzyl electrophiles. Taking advantage of the C2 -symmetry of the cyclindrocyclophane scaffold, we hope to synthesize a complex coupling fragment bearing both electrophiles, then construct the entire scaffold through a double reductive cross -coupling. We wil l explore the use of a sterically encumbered N -hydroxyphthalimide esters in a model system to effect this transformation. To this end, we report on the development and optimization of this asymmetric cross -coupling to afford an advanced intermediate in the synthesis of the cylindrocyclophane scaffold. 102 Investigating Molecular Interaction Between Anti -Freeze Protein and Biological Markers Joshua J. Lugo Mentors: William Andrew Goddard III , Xin Wen Soo -Kyung Kim Antifreeze proteins (AFPs) are biopolymers known to inhibit the growth of ice crystals. Through enzymatic activity assays of lactate dehydrogenase the AFP Dendroides canadensis (DAFP- 1) has been shown to also exhi bit thermal protective behaviors, and prevent aggregation of ADH. Both LDH and ADH are biological markers important for metabolism. We're analyzing the molecular interaction between DAFP- 1 and these biological markers using Maestro, Pymol, Visual Molecular Dynamics (VMD), and Nanoscale Molecular Dynamics (NAMD) software. This allows us to determine the best orientations and likely residues of interaction between molecules and discern if it would be energetically favorable for them to interact in a water sol ution. Initial dynamics show DAFP- 1's LYS 65 and ARG 33 residues are capable of forming salt bridges and hydrogen bonds with ADH's chain A and B's GLU 249 residues. Additionally, DAFP -1's ASP 20, 45 residues can form these bonds with LDH's ARG 98, 111 resi dues. Energetic favorability is still being determined though further dynamics. Knowing the interaction points allows us to better understand the mechanisms behind AFPs which may elucidate how some organisms can survive during extreme weather and expand po tential applications of AFPs in various fields. Experimental Design and Implementation of a Mach- Zehnder Interferometer Alfonso Mares Mentors: Beverley McKeon and David Huynh Skin friction drag is an issue that has been prevalent since early flights of planes. An approach to reduce skin friction drag that has been studied in the past is compliant surfaces. Even though compliant surfaces have been noted to reduce skin friction d rag (Gad -el-Hak 2002) in some cases, not much is known about the interaction of compliant surfacing and turbulence. An important requirement when studying this interaction is being able to measure the deformations. A well known method of measuring small d istances is interferometry, and specifically a Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) would be able to measure the deformations properly through the experimentation process. This summer project seeks to provide a proof of concept of a functional MZI, that will later be used in the NOAH water tunnel in a compliant surface study. In the process of designing the MZI, to further develop a better understanding of interferometry, a simple Michelson interferometer was constructed. Data from the interference pattern of the Michelson was collected to make a sample analysis in MATLAB. Modelling and Analyzing Epidural Electrode Spinal Cord Stimulation in Paralyzed Patients Sonia Moreno Mentors: Joel W. Burdick and Ellen Feldman Electrical spinal cord stimulation is used to improve the mobility of paraplegics . By stimulating specific areas of the spinal cord, we can mimic the signals sent from the brain to the limbs, allowing paraplegics to regain motor movement. This is achieved by placing an array of electrodes inside the epidural fat of the spinal cord. A research group at UCLA is running trials using a 32 -electrode array, collecting the EMG data, and giving the patients scores on a scale of one to 7. In my research, I modelled the stimulation of a 32 -electrode array in the spinal cord. I will then be using machine learning techniques including linear regression and classification to find correlations between the EMG data and patient scores, and eventually between the simulation data and the EMG data. Local Chemical Environments in Magnetic "High Entropy" Alloys Daniel Mukasa Mentor: Brent Fultz Chemical and magnetic ordering in the face -centered cubic high entropy alloy FeCoCrNiAl2 were investigated. The materials were subjected to thermal treatments by various methods including melt spinning and arc melting followed by quenching from various temperatures. Previously measured magnetic properties have shown a dependence on thermal treatment, raising the belief that such treatments have altered the local chemical environments in this multicomponent alloy. The local chemical arrangements around Fe atoms were studied by 57Fe Mossbauer spectroscopy at both room temperature and at 77K where the samples are strongly ferromagneti c. Preliminary results show that the different thermal treatments altered the local chemical environments in the alloy. These results will be correlated to changes in the bulk magnetic properties with thermal treatment. Changes in the configurational entro py of these "high entropy" alloys will also be estimated. Non-Absorbing Freeze Cast Ceramics for Flow -Through Pathogen Filtration Natalie Nicolas Mentors: Katherine Faber and Noriaki Arai Porous polymer -derived silicon oxycarbide fabricated by freeze casting has great potential as a diagnostic membrane for flow -through pathogen filtration due to its unique, tunable pore structure. By freeze casting polysiloxane preceramic polymers dissolved in cyclohexane, it is possible to create highly porous ceramic membranes with aligned dendritic pores. This project focuses on reducing the free carbon phase in these silicon 103 oxycarbide membranes to reduce the ceramic's light absorbance. This would allow the membranes to be used in the diagnosis of disease by size- separating and temporarily trapping pathogens for identification via fluorescent tags. Free carbon reduction is carried out through the addition of water vapor during pyrolysis, which can reduce the amount of carbon to less than 25% of the original value and increase the reflectance of the sample from less than 10% to more than 80% over the relevant wavelengths. This could greatly improve the ceramic's performance in applications where light must be seen through the sample, including in diagnostic applications. Development of a Test Section for Modeling Volcanic Jets by Using Multiphase Flow to Simulate Gravitational Loading David Norris Mentors: Joanna Austin and Ryan (Yichuan) Song Understanding how multiphase flows of erupting volcanos affect their surrounding areas is important for predicting hazards. For example, during the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens, the entire northern side of the mountain and nearby forest was obliterate d through the expulsion of high speed gases and debris. Many computational models have been developed in the past to simulate volcanic jets, but experimental validation of such models, to date, has been lacking. The long -term goal of this project is to sim ulate the combined effects of gas decompression and gravitational loading on a multiphase flow in the laboratory. As a first step, designing and building a test chamber presents unique challenges. The design must minimize pressure rise and reflected waves due to jet activation, allow optical access for diagnostics, be capable of restraining the magnetic assembly designed to induce a gravitational analog body force on the flow, and safely contain metallic microparticles used to transfer force to the fluid. W e chose to pursue an iterative design process and produced a proof of concept using off -the-shelf parts to test various parameters intrinsic to the experiment. This setup allowed us to test our sensor setup and gave us a better understanding of the volume and backpressure constraints that will be used to finalize the design. Structured Antireflective Coating for Silicon at Submillimeter Frequencies Estefania Padilla Gonzalez Mentor: Sunil Golwala Observations at millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths are useful for many astronomical studies, like the polarization of the cosmic microwave background or the formation and evolution of galaxy clusters. In order to allow observations over a broad spect ral bandwidth (approximatively from 70 to 420 GHz), innovative broadband anti-reflective (AR) optics must be utilized in submillimeter telescopes. Due to its low loss and high refractive index, silicon is a good optical material at these frequencies, but a n AR coating with multiple layers is required to maximize its transmission over a wide bandwidth. Structured multilayer AR coatings for silicon are currently being developed at Caltech and JPL. The development process includes the design of the structured layers with commercial electromagnetic simulation software, the fabrication by using deep reactive ion etching, and the test of the transmission and reflection of the patterned wafers. Geometrical 3D patterns have successfully been etched at the surface of the silicon wafers creating up to 2 layers with different effective refractive indices. The transmission and reflection of single AR layer wafers, measured between 75 and 330 GHz, are close to the simulation predictions. These results allow the development of new designs with 5 or 6 AR layers in order to improve the bandwidth and transmission of the silicon AR coatings. The Synthesis of New, Stabilized Cr Aryl Precursors for Mechanistic Studies of Ethylene Tetramerization Catalysis Danny Perez Mentors: T heodor Agapie and Nathanael A. Hirscher Chromium -based catalysts have been targeted for selective catalytic ethylene tetramerization on industrial scales for over a decade. However, a lack of fundamental understanding of the catalyst activation process and chromium coordination environment have hindered full development of this system. Novel organochromium precursors were synthesized to provide evidence for metallocyclic intermediates in the catalytic cycle. Crystal structures of novel arylated precursors were obtained by x -ray crystallography. Reactions with isopropyl -PNP and dilithiobutane were performed to test for reactivity and stability of the Cr products. Chromium complexes were synthesized under inert atmosphere and anhydrous conditions. Cr -containi ng products were characterized by GC/MS and X -ray crystallography, and 1H NMR was used to characterize organic products. Determining Nucleotide Interactions W ith the Iron Protein of Nitrogenase Using X -Ray Crystallography Gerardo Perez and Belinda Wenke The Haber -Bosch process is the industrial process of nitrogen fixation. It is widely used, combining heat, high pressure, and metal catalysts for highly efficient nitrogen fixation. Nature fixes nitrogen in a much different fashion, using the nitrogenase e nzymatic system to catalyze the ATP- dependent reduction of N 2. However, a gap in our understanding of the enzymatic system lies in the structural intermediates, specifically that of the ATP bound state of the iron (Fe) protein subunit of nitrogenase. Such structural studies are carried out by X -ray 104 crystallography, where the purified protein of interest is crystallized, the crystal is shot with a beam of X -rays, and then the diffraction pattern from the crystal is used to obtain a structure of the crystalli zed protein. The results show that the conditions sampled were not optimal for the growth of crystals of the ATP bound state of the Fe protein. Continuing work will be on finding better conditions for crystal growth, with the final goal being to shoot them at the beamline if suitable crystals can be grown. Low-Jitter Superconducting Nanowire Single Photon Detectors Edward Ramirez, California State U niversity, Los Angeles Mentors: Matthew Shaw, Boris Korzh, and Simone Frasca, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology One critical parameter of Superconducting Nanowire Single Photon Detectors (SNSPDs) is jitter , which is also known as the temporal resolution and is the uncertainty of the photon arrival time . SNSPDs operate at temperatures below 1K, are relatively small (µ m), and yield high efficiencies (>90%). However, the fundamental limits of the timing jitter are still poorly understood. Thus, the goal of this project is to reduce the geometric and noise jitter, so that we can begin to understand intrinsic jitter. Only devices that yield a high bias current with an amplifier at room temperature will be studied inside a cryostat. The cryostat will operate at 0.8K, and the temporal jitter will be measured by flood illuminating the sample chips with a femto -second fiber -coupled mode -locked laser. The temporal jitter will be measured by generating a hi stogram of the delay times between the detection events and reference pulse from a fast optical diode that i s measured on a 12Ghz oscilloscope. Currently, we've measured a low jitter of < 10ps, and have related high bias current to low jitter. Evidence from experimental work suggests that intrinsic jitter has dependence on energy and temperature. Investigating the Role of Estrogen Receptor 1 (Esr1)+ Signaling in Various Forms of Aggression Ashley St. John Mentors: David J. Anderson, Moriel Zelikowsky, and May Hui Defensive behaviors such as fear and aggression are important for survival, however these can be come detrimental when triggered in excess. The neural underpinnings associated with these emotional behaviors has yet to be fully elucidated. Previous studies have pinpointed a neuronal population in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMHvl), estrogen receptor 1 (Esr1)+ neurons, as sufficient to generate aggression (Lee et al. 2014). Increase in activation of this cell population influenced the progression of aggressive social behaviors exhibited in transgenic mice. This project investigates the potential corre lation between aggression and the upregulation of Esr1a+ neurons with a particular focus on differential forms of aggression induced by various environmental conditions. Using the resident -intruder assay and video record tracking in order to annotate the d ifferent behaviors displayed, we tested the effects of various forms of experience on aggressive behavior and the brain. The experience conditions were group housing, sexual experience, social isolation and PTSD/inescapable foot shocks. The subsequent behaviors annotated for include investigation, mount, and attack behaviors. We then used immunohistochemistry techniques and fluorescence microscopy to stain and image for Esr1a receptors in the brain. Identification of fluorescent tags of Esr1 receptors and cell populations may offer further understanding of the role of Esr1 neurons mediated aggression produced by various environmental stimuli. Design and Implementation of a Fan Array Wind Tunnel Distributed Control System for Multicopter Drone Research Alejandro A. Stefan Zavala Mentor: Beverley J. McKeon The open-loop DC fan array wind tunnels developed at GALCIT are a cheaper and more versatile alternative to traditional wind tunnels for testing multi-copter drones. The current design, however, using DC computer fans controlled with Pulse Width Modulation, necessitates a system capable of simultaneously generating independent PWM signals and adjusting for the speed imprecisions in each fan. Moreover, generating a volume of "useful" flow large enough to effectively test "medium -sized" drones — of approximately 350mm between opposite propellers — a square array of over a hundred fans is needed. The solution found is a system comprised by a set of microcontroller boards, each controlling a portion of the array, connected over a Local Area Network to a "server" computer. The network is scalable to control an arbitrary number of fans; and uses the Hal sensor tachometers in each fan to more precisely control their speeds in a closed feedback loop. Development of Microfluidic Methods for Immune Cell Expansion Microscopy Daniom Tecle Mentor: James Heath Cancer immunotherapy is an emerging class of treatment that harnesses the immune system to annihilate malignant cells. In particular, the blockade of checkpoint molecules (PD -1 and CTLA -4), which normally suppress tumor -infiltrated immune cells, is becoming a potent therapy for several cancers. Unfortunately, many cancers do not respond to checkpoint blockade, likely due to the presence of other immune suppressive mechanisms that are not fully understood. Thus, there is a need to study the tumor microenviro nment, especially the phenotype of the 105 suppressed tumor -infiltrated immune population. However, routine single -cell proteomic techniques require large amounts sample (> 1 million cells), and are either limited in multiplexing capacity (FACs) or destroys the cells that are analyzed (CyTOF). The main goal of our project is to develop a complimentary, sample efficient method that can perform multiplexed proteomic analysis of intact immune cells at the subcellular level. This new method will rely on microfluidi cs for liquid handling, expansion microscopy to enhance the optical resolution, and temporal multi-color barcoding for multiplexing. In the past several months, we have made great strides toward the development of this method. We optimized a microfluidic d roplet generator that can form high- yield cell -gel droplets for expansion microscopy. We also designed and tested a prototype cell -gel trap device, which will eventually enable the implementation of a temporal barcoding workflow that can probe at least 20 proteins in hundreds of single cells. Electrolytes in Confinement Walther Villatoro Mentors: Konstantinos Giapis and Ben Kanevsky Fuel cells are envisioned as an alternative to combustion engines for conversion of chemical to electrical energy due to the ir higher efficiency. However, the increased efficiency of fuel cells still does not outweigh the costs associated with materials of construction. Therefore, it is necessary to continue to reduce energy losses and further reduce the cost. One way to increa se the efficiency is to improve the performance of the electrolyte membrane in fuel cells. To this aim we studied the effects of confinement on the ionic transport properties of cesium dihydrogen phosphate (CDP). At a temperature of about 230 C, it undergo es a super protonic phase transition which increases its ionic conductivity by several orders of magnitude. It is possible that CDP confined to nanoscale size may be more beneficial for fuel cell applications because nano materials are known to have differ ent properties than those in the bulk. The ideal result was having the temperature of the phase transition occur at a lower temperature. For this study, CDP was confined in anodized aluminum oxide (AAO) as it is composed of a network of hexagonally packed highly ordered pores. The CDP filled AAO membrane was treated as a circuit composed of a resistor and capacitor in parallel to calculate conductivity. This made it necessary to use another superconductor, AgI, as a reference to troubleshoot calculation methods due to the limited amount of data available for CDP. The pure and filled AAO membranes were characterized using alternating current impedance spectroscopy (ACIS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The SEM and EDS images confirmed the presence of the desired material within the pores of AAO. Future work involves using the ACIS data to calculate the conductivity of CDP. Aeroela stic Divergence of Swept Trey Weber Mentors: Beverley McKeon , Michael Ortiz, and Arnold Deffo Nde In prioritizing the different aspects of aircraft design, structural integrity is of great importance. In light of this, aeroelasticity explores the relationship between aerodynamic and structural forces. One of the many aeroelastic phenomena that must be accounted for is divergence. Divergence of a wing occurs when an applied load and the resulting deflections interact, creating a feedback loop that can lead to catastrophic failure. The airspee d at which this becomes a factor is generally difficult to calculate analytically for a wing with non- constant spanwise properties. For a similar wing model, we aim to find a relationship between the divergence dynamic pressure and the wing sweep angle. The governing equations are coupled, high order differential equations. A numerical solution using the finite difference method has allowed us to quantify both the deflection and twist along the span of the wing. By comparing data for different sweep angles , we can conclude that sweeping the wings back 2 -4 degrees or more causes the divergence dynamic pressure to approach infinity. Thus, we are able to eliminate divergence as a factor in the structural design of an aircraft with backward swept wings. Analy sis of Potential Radical Chemistry on Kuiper Belt Objects Maya D. Boulder 2NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs) are of high interest following the New Horizons encounter with the Pluto system and the extended mission to 2014MU69. We aimed to clarify questions raised concerning the possible presence of organic radicals formed from photolysis on the surface of KBOs and other Trans -Neptunian Objects, and obtain laboratory spectra of these radicals for comparison to remote sensing data. We explored the photochemical generation of methyl radical from matrix -isolated CH 3I in an attempt to create sufficient amounts of the m ethyl radical to obtain spectra in the near infrared. Both Ar and N 2 matrices were studied, as well as varying guest:matrix ratios. Hydrogen lamp irradiation was found to be more effective than mercury lamp irradiation. The irradiation time was a signifi cant factor when we switched matrices: methyl radical depleted rapidly in the N 2 matrix with prolonged irradiation (~10 hours) whereas it survived for over 48 hours in some experiments with the Ar matrix. Reaction of the methyl radical with the N 2 matrix to form HCN was observed. Future experiments will focus on alternate methods of radical generation in order to increase the yield of trapped radical. Amgen Scholars Program A M G E N AMGEN 109 Arsenic Resistance and Extended Lifespan in New Species of Nematodes Found in Mono Lake Jean Badroos Mentors: Paul Sternberg and Amir Sapir At least six new unique nematode species have been found in Mono Lake. Due to the lake's high arsenic levels and basic pH, these nematodes are characterized as extremophiles with phenotypes of arsenic resistance, a life span nearly twice as long as the average nematode, and other notable phenotypes. By comparing these nematodes to c. elegans , a phosphorus -like biochemistry —and its direct or indirect effect on aging can be determined. For a thorough understanding of these species, the nematodes needed new culturing methods developed to grow them at a mass scale. With enough worms, a complete profiling of the worms' environmental conditions, morphology, and general 18s sequence was analyzed. In addition to abiotic factors, the microbiota of the worms and their soil environment to study potential factors in their bacterial 16s sequence. To more completely understand the nematodes, their genomes are vital in determining the gene family responsible for arsenic resistance. The significance or relation of skn -1, pcs -1, hmt- 1, the MAPK pathway, and newly found arse nic resistant genes found via EMS were also studied to identify any potential pathways. Ultimately, a deeper knowledge of arsenic resistance and its relation to aging will be developed. Strobilation Effects on Regeneration in Aurelia Polyps Paola Benefo Mentors: Lea Goentoro and David Gold An emerging model cnidarian is the moon jellyfish, Aurelia . It has a complex life cycle with different stages demonstrating differing degrees of regenerative potential between the two main stages: the polyp and medusa. The polyp produces asexual clones through constant cell proliferation, and it can go through a series of metamorphoses, called strobilation, producing multiple young medusa before returning to its original form. Conversely, the medusa sexually reproduces and has limited regenerative potential, which is restricted to specific developmental times and tissues. The transition from an "immortal" polyp to a "senescing" medusa is what the Goentoro lab is working to understand. My project examines the ability of p olyps to regenerate tissues after they have produced young medusa. In this regard, I am assaying whether there is cellular competition between maintaining the polyp body and producing young medusas. My hypothesis is that after a strobilation event, the polyp exhibits evidence of senescence, at least temporarily. If correct, then I predict that, following strobilation, the ability to regenerate damaged tissues decreases, cell proliferation rates decrease, and asexual budding decreases. This hypothesis is te sted by recording regeneration of a polyp head, the rate of bud production, and using EdU to record the rate of proliferation. This experiment will illustrate how regeneration is maintained throughout the Aurelia life cycle. Chemically Functionalized Crys talline Silicon Surfaces With Molecular Dipoles for Solar -Driven Hydrogen Generation Daniel E. Del Toro -Pedrosa Mentors: Nathan S. Lewis and Miguel Caban- Acevedo Among renewable energy sources, solar energy is considered to be one of the most promising given that the Sun irradiates the earth with petawatts of energy at any given time. However, in order for solar energy to become a viable energy sources, storage of daylight energy in the form of a chemical fuel is necessary in order to overcome the challenges associated with the intermittent nature of sunlight. In this regard, solar water splitting electrochemical cells are promising integrated devices that take sunlight as input and produce hydrogen as a solar fuel. In this study, w e worked on improving the energetic alignment of p-silicon semiconductor with high work function hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts through chemical functionalization with molecular dipoles. Specifically, we looked at the integration of platinum w ith functionalized p-silicon surfaces using spray coating as soft contacting method. First, we synthesized Pt nanocubes with diameters of 7 nm which we characterized through transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X -ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Then, we investigated spray coating conditions to prepare films with different degrees of coverage and post- annealing conditions to remove the ligands from the Pt nanocube surfaces. Finally, we integrated the nanoparticles directly on functionalized p-silicon surfaces and measured the semiconductor/catalyst junction properties through electrochemical measurements. Our results suggest that post- annealing conditions needed to remove the Pt nanocube ligands are too harsh for functionalized p-silicon surfaces with o rganic molecules. In future work, we will investigate if graphene can protect organic monolayers on p-silicon surface and enable integration with metal catalyst nanoparticles. Length and Time Scales of Cell -Cell Signaling Circuits in Agar Joy Doong Mentor s: Richard Murray and James Parkin Genetic networks are typically built for uniform and well -mixed cell cultures; however, a mixed and coordinated community of cells living in a heterogeneous environment allows for more sophisticated operations than uniform cultures. To establish the principles to engineer reliable cell -cell communication in a heterogeneous environment, we have identified the range of length and time scales over which patterns form by assaying simple quorum 110 sensing communication circuits in semisolid media preparations. I have constructed "sender" and "receiver" strains, which respectively produce and respond to a small chemical inducer, with signaling circuits of different topologies and parts and recorded the fluorescence response of receiver cell colonies to the sender colonies in various spatial arrangements. I have found that single colony of one sender strain variant is sufficient to induce receiver response at more than 2cm separation. Furthermore, receiver colonies expressing signal degradase respond with a time delay and reduce the response in immediate ly subsequent receiver colonies. In essence, calling distance and signal delay are predictable properties tunable by exchanging circuit parts. I am working towards applying the observed characteristics to enable a dynamic two -dimensional patterning of colo nies, and thereby demonstrate control over the length and time scale of the communication circuits. In Search of Neurons Controlling Sexually Dimorphic Threat Displays Jered W. Everson Mentor s: David Anderson and Brian J. Duistermars Male fruit flies (Drosophila) engage in multi -component threat displays with dynamic wing elevation, forward charging, and active orientation. Previously, a post- doc named Brian Duistermars in David Anderson's laboratory at Caltech isolated a small cluster of neurons controlling this threat behavior in males. These identified neurons are both necessary and sufficient for multi -component threat displays. Studies have revealed a sexual dimorphism in the pattern and expression of threat displays in male and fe male flies. Fru, short for the aptly -named fruitless gene, is a sex determination gene that specifies sex specific circuitry. Four of the neurons identified in the wing threat cluster are positive for Fru expression in males. Interestingly, females also ap pear to have two less neurons in this cluster, which invokes the hypothesis that Fru expression in females causes the death of two neurons in this cluster, thus leading to the sex -specific pattern of threats observed. In a preliminary experiment, we found that stimulating threat neurons in males, with a temperature sensitive ion channel expressed in these neurons (TRPA1), causes them to threaten moving objectives of various velocities. Activating these neurons at the same temperature in females, however, di d not achieve the same result. As such, our principal aims are to quantify the fundamental differences between male and female threat displays, affirm that sex specific Fru expression is integral for sexually dimorphic displays, elucidate the molecular and functional circuitry of the neurons that confer sexually dimorphic threat displays, and establish which combination(s) of stimuli (e.g. pheromones, visual motion, experience, etc.) are necessary and/or sufficient to elicit threat displays. Nonaqueous Scr eening of Bimetallic Catalysts for CO 2 Electroreduction to Hydrocarbon Products Elizabeth Hallett Mentors: Nathan S. Lewis and Daniel A. Torelli The electrochemical reduction of CO 2 to hydrocarbon fuels provides a means to store intermittent solar and other renewable energies. The most active catalysts known for CO 2 reduction are largely copper based, and have prohibitively high overpotentials and low selectivities. Copper -free bimetallic catalysts are a promising route to highly reduced products at low ov erpotentials, as combining metals can allow for the tuning of catalyst selectivity and performance. In this work, nickel and iron based bimetallic catalysts were synthesized by solvothermal methods. A total of 13 bimetallic combinations were tested for rea ctivity towards CO 2 reduction in acetonitrile and methanol. Each catalyst was screened under N 2, CO 2, and CO. Cyclic voltammograms in each environment were compared and catalysts which displayed the greatest current difference from N 2 to CO 2 or CO were fu rther characterized by chronoamperometry. Gaseous products generated by these catalysts were analyzed by gas chromatography and liquid products by proton NMR. C1 -C3 products were detected along with CO and H 2 gas at various faradaic efficiencies. Ni 2Al3 and Fe 2Co3 were among the most active catalysts and their surfaces should be characterized to ensure the formation of stable alloys. Electrolyses should also be performed in aqueous solutions, which are more suitable for large scale use. Predicting Cellular Responses to Three or More Signaling Proteins Using Pairwise Responses Only Samuel Huang Mentors: Michael Elowitz and Heidi Klumpe Combinations of BMPs (Bone Morphogenetic Proteins) regulate development in multiple tissues, but how these signaling proteins combine to produce the overall cell response remains unclear. Recently, our lab showed that cells respond to ratios of different BMP pairs, rather than merely the sum. However, more than two BMPs signal simultaneously in most developmental syste ms. Therefore, quantifying responses to three or more BMPs could reveal new principles of signal integration, such as whether responses to BMP combinations can be predicted from responses to pairs. In addition to regenerating previously observed pairwise r esponses, I measured responses to BMP triplets across the dynamic range of each ligand. Large deviations from predicted additive responses likely indicate an emergent interaction of all three ligands that could not be predicted from responses to pairs. We also measured cell responses to all possible combinations of 5 BMPs of interest, generalizing our analysis to combinations of more than three BMPs. These results help us understand which BMPs combine non- additively and to what extent, which will be useful for understanding known developmental signals and developing BMP therapies. 111 Interoception and I ts Relationship to Prospection and Retrospection Samantha L. Jensen Mentor: Cindy Hagan Research suggests that aberrant interoceptive processes - an individual's sensitivity to interior physiological states like breathing, heartbeat, or hunger - may be related to mood disorders such as anxiety and major depressive disorders. We hypothesize that this relationship is due to the influence of the interoceptive experience on the formation of memories and expectations of interoceptive states. In a population with healthy variation in symptoms of anxiety and depression we will administer two assessments of interoceptive awareness: one which mea sures individual awareness of interoceptive ability and another which measures individual sensitivity to fluctuations in interoceptive states. We aim to determine whether the vividity of both interoceptive memories and forecasting of interoceptive experiences are positively correlated with confidence in interoceptive awareness. In this talk we present new paradigms for the administration and analysis of respiratory and cardiac interoceptive testing, including hardware and real -time computational pipelines, as well as empirical measures of retrospection and prospection. Exploring the Effect of Curli on Huntingtin Protein Oligomerization and Aggregation in Addison Lana Mentor: Ali Khoshnan Huntington's Disease (HD) is a genetically inherited neurodegenerative disease caused by an abnormal expansion of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) in exon- 1 of the Huntingtin gene. Post- translation, mutant Huntingtin protein with an abnormally expanded polyglutamine region are pro cessed into smaller neurotoxic fragments that result in disease progression. However, years before individuals with HD experience symptom manifestation; high levels of plasma inflammatory cytokines are observed, suggesting there might be environmental factors also influencing disease progression. To investigate the environmental effects of host gut microbiota on brain health and longevity in HD subjects, this project focuses on curli, a highly inflammatory amyloid protein secreted by Escherichia coli for structure and colonization purposes known to affect disease progression. My project will investigate curli's effect on Huntingtin protein aggregation, oligomerization and disease progression in an HD Drosophila model through comparing results in Immunohistochemistry staining, long -term memory, and motor function assays between mutant and wild type flies. Controlled C -H Oxidation Catalyzed by Ni -Fe Layered Double Hydroxide Nanoparticles Daniel P. Marron Mentors: Harry B. Gray and Bryan M. Hunter A recently characterized mixed -transition- metal water oxidation catalyst was found to perform controlled C -H activation and oxidation under anodic bias. Electrocatalytic oxidation was probed with the catalyst supported on high-porosity electrodes (carbon fibe r paper, CFP) and chemically inert glassy carbon (GC) electrodes. Oxidation of a simple model substrate, diphenylmethane, showed that the catalytic CFP electrodes, when operated at 1.4 V vs. a Pt wire pseudoreference, achieved complete conversion with grea ter than 90% Faradaic efficiency. The CFP by itself did not show detectible conversion at this potential. A flow cell was designed and constructed for use with catalytic glassy carbon electrodes, and a variety of substrates were tested to determine functio nal group compatibility with the water oxidation catalyst. Functional groups assessed were alkenes (e.g. cyclohexene), amines (e.g. tetramethylammonium hexafluro phosphate). In cases where multiple functional groups were present, selective C -H activation was observed. Moving forward, we hope to expand the library of oxidizable substrates to include pharmacologically -relevant molecules and large -scale processes of i nterest to industrial partners. We also hope to explore the potential -dependence of product distributions, which has been observed in the conversion of toluene to benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde. Synthetic Genetic Systems to Identify Wiring Diagrams of th e Brain Peter Niesman Mentors: Carlos Lois and Ting -Hao Huang A detailed map of neural circuits is required for scientists to understand how the nervous system functions. Current tools to identify neuronal contacts in the brain still depend on previous knowledge of which neurons may connect. Our system, TRanscellular ACtivation of Transcription (TRACT), is based on the Delta/Notch pathway. By linking the transgenic ligand (CD19) of TRACT to synaptobrevin, a protein involved in vesicle release and localized to synapses, we have been able to selectively identify neurona l contacts instead of more general cell -cell contacts. We are using TRACT to examine possible connectivity between the optic lobe and the circadian neurons in adult Drosophila . Additionally, we are using TRACT to examine the synaptic partners of circadian neurons in Drosophila . Using immunohistochemistry and confocal microscopy, we can visualize and trace neuronal connections between different subsets of neurons in the optic lobe and determine whether they connect to neurons important for 112 circadian behavio r directly or indirectly. We have shown that pigment dispersing factor (PDF) neurons in Drosophila larvae make contacts with neurons expressing period protein. We will be able to show the relationship between neurons in the optic lobe of adult Drosophila a nd circadian neurons. Progress Toward the Synthesis of Subincanadine F Winston Odom Mentors: Brian Stoltz, Caleb Hethcox, and Samantha Shockley Subincanadine an indole exhibits cytotoxicity against murine lymphoma and human epidermis carcinoma in vitro. This project aims to develop the most efficient enantioselective synthesis of subincanadine F using a novel -arylation reaction. This strategy provides access to the natural product in a rapid four steps from known compounds. Using Rational Design and Large -Scale Library Approaches to Engineer HIV Immunogens Ana Jimena Pavlovitch- Bedzyk Mentors: Pamela Bjorkman, Anthony West, and Harry Gristick HIV-1 continues to be a global health priority. In 2015 alone, an estimated 2.1 million people were newly diagnosed with HIV -1, 150,000 of whom were children (WHO, 2015). The virus harbors the capability to maintain function while varying its antigenic surface, thereby evading the adaptive immune response (Haynes et al., 2012). This becomes particularly problematic whe n implementing a common approach to vaccine development: the induction of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) against conserved epitopes to confer broad and lasting protection. While it is widely accepted that variability in viral glycoproteins prevents the successful development of antibody based HIV -1 therapies and vaccines, new studies highlight the potential of antibodies targeting the conserved CD4 binding site (CD4bs) of HIV -1 gp120. Two such antibodies are VRC01 and IOMA, isolated from HIV - 1 infe cted patients several years into the infection (Jardine et al., 2015; Gristick et al., 2016). The presence of these antibodies offers the unique opportunity to neutralize the virus before it is able to establish infection. Though VRC01 confers broader and more potent protection, it also contains extensive somatic hypermutations and a short, variable light chain third complementarity -determining region (LCDR3). Because the mature form of IOMA harbors fewer somatic hypermutations and has a shorter, more commo n length LCDR3, we hypothesize that IOMA -like Abs will be easier to elicit. The version of immunogen necessary to do so has yet to be fully elucidated. Our lab recently solved a crystal structure of an IOMA Fab in complex with a soluble Envelope (Env) trim er, revealing the molecular details of the IOMA -gp120 interaction. Using this structure as a guide, we used a combination of rational design and large -scale library approaches to engineer a gp120 -based immunogen that will that will bind the inferred germli ne of IOMA with high affinity. Host Molecule Probes for Pi -Pi Interactions Diane Rafizadeh Mentors: Theodor Agapie and Jessica Sampson Pi-pi interactions in nature play key roles in stabilizing biological macromolecules —such as DNA —and in their interacti ons with small molecules. We have designed and synthesized small molecule hosts potentially capable of engaging with various biologically - and environmentally -relevant substrates by taking advantage of the interaction between extended pi systems to sense g uest molecules. The hosts, or ligands, we have developed consist of a dipyridyl cyclic urea backbone, which can engage in hydrogen bonding with a substrate, flanked by aromatic substituents capable of pi -pi stacking above and below the guest's aromatic sys tem. Bimetallic late transition metal complexes supported by these ligands have been targeted with potential for further study of their reactivity towards small molecule substrates. Future experiments will determine specificity of these hosts, both metalla ted and unmetallated, for particular biological and inorganic substrates. Approaches in Caenorhabditis Revanna Mentors: Paul Sternberg and Han Wang Genome editing techniques using clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats, also known as the CRISPR -Cas9 system, have revolutionized the genetics field by allowing a more targeted approach. CRISPR -Cas9 has been used widely among many model organisms, including the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans . CRISPR - Cas9 has generating knockouts through genetically -targeted deletions , making precise modifications using homology directed repair (HDR), activating or repressing targeted genes, and more. In order to activate or repress genes, CRISPR may be used in conjunction with a deactivated Cas9 (dCas9), which lacks endonuclease activity; the CRISPR -dCas9 system requires an attachment of a transcription factor that will either upregulate or downregulate the gene. Currently, there is lack of dCas9 research in nematodes, therefore we plan to optimize CRISPR activation (CRISPRa). We have assembled a dCas9 construct with VP64 and VPR, which are strong transcriptional activators. In addition, we have constructed a dCas9 plasmid utilizing a SunTag fusion protein, 113 which can bind 10 copies of the transcription factor to the targeted genomic site. We have chosen lin- 3 as our candidate target gene because of its well -documented and easi ly observed multivulva phenotype. This system would offer a robust, efficient way of activating genes in order to study their functions. Stability of Cobalt Phosphide Coatings on a Variety of Different Substrates Elijah Schiltz -Rouse Mentor s: Nathan Lewis and Xinghao Zhou Cobalt Phosphide is an excellent catalyst for the Hydrogen evolution reaction in acidic and basic conditions. The determination of exactly how it breaks down in solution is challenging but important to improving it's catalytic efficiency. Here, we study Co balt Phosphide on a variety of substrates and how the pH of the electrolytic solution effect's it's stability using electrochemical data, a scanning electron microscope, and energy dispersive spectrometry. Despite research suggesting high catalytic activity in acid, we find that the high cobalt concentration in electrodeposited layers leads to instability. Our results support the premise that electrodeposited Cobalt Phosphide is more stable in basic electrolytes. Investigating the Effects of Gut Microbiota on Orb2A in a Model of Huntington's Disease Tiffany Tsou Mentor: Ali Khoshnan The gut- brain axis between the enteric nervous system and the central nervous system links gastrointestinal health and cognition. This phenomenon is heavily influenced by the g ut microbiota, as bacterial metabolites and food are absorbed together by nutritional uptake of the intestines to fuel the brain. Gut dysbiosis is the imbalance of host gut bacteria, symptomatic of various neurodegenerative diseases such as Huntington's di sease (HD), yet the relationship between neurodegenerative cognitive impairment and gut microbiota remains unknown. To study this potential connection, we are examining the Orb2A protein- encoding mRNA expression of antibiotic treated and antibiotic non- treated Drosophila melanogaster in an HD model. Orb2A is an amyloidogenic protein that is a facilitator of long -term memory formation, shown to interact with the misfolded protein in HD known as Huntingtin. We utilize the Rifaximin antibiotic to deplete the f lies of their gut microbiota and reverse transcriptase -PCR to establish the effects of gut microbes on the splicing of Orb2A mRNA. Understanding the potential contribution of gut microbes to long -term memory will further the discourse on neurodegeneration in Huntington's disease. CCDC141 and Trunk Neural Crest Migration Van Anderlecht Mentors: Marianne Bronner and Felipe Vieceli Neural crest cells (NCC) are a vertebrate exclusive embryonic cell population specified at the neural plate border after gastrulation and before neural tube formation. After neurulation, these cells migrate throughout the embryo to reach defined targets where they differentiate. Factors that control cytoskeleton dynamics play crucial roles in promoting the migration behavior of the NCC and thus proper formation of its derived structures . This project investigates the expression and requirement of CCDC141 , a coiled -coil domain containing protein shown to regulate centrosome positioning and migration of neural progenitors in the developing cortex, during NCC migration, suggested by previous RNA sequencing data. We first analyz ed its expression in the chicken embryo with in situ hybridization to elucidate CCDC141 expression pattern. T he data suggests that CCDC141 is already present in pre-migratory NCC at stage HH8 , but we were not able to detect expression in migrating trunk NCC in older stages, where expression was mainly observed in the developing heart and somites . We have also generated DNA constructs to allow expression of two CCDC141 guide RNAs , and loss-of-function experiments using CRISPR/Cas9 will be performed to verify if CCDC141 is required in migrating NCC. Causal Analysis of Brain Imaging Data to Understand the Minds of Split -Brain Patients Christine Yin Mentors: Frederick Eberhardt and Ralph Adolphs The corpus callosum is the largest connective structure in the brain that connects the left and right hemispheres. Agenesis of the corpus callosum (AgCC) is when the corpus callosum fails to develop. Previous studies have found in AgCC individuals that there is functional correlation between homotopic cortical regions in the left and right hemispheres, or in other words, corresponding analogous structures on each side of the brain. Functional networks can emerge in the absence of the corpus callosum with development of normal cognition and behavior. Earlier work by our group demonstrated that the two hemispheres of the brain communicate information with each other (interhemispheric information transfer) in AgCC indivduals. How does functional connec tivity arise in the absence of the corpus callosum? The research aims to develop a causal model for how this arises. In this study, eight resting state fMRI scans were taken of an individual with complete agenesis of the corpus callosum. The data was prepr ocessed with FreeSurfer and then run through causal algorithms with an eliminatory approach to find the indirect causal link that gives rise to functional connectivity in the absence of the corpus callosum. It is hypothesized that the indirect causal link is a subcortical driver. The Laser Interferometer Gravitational -Wave Observatory L I G O LIGO 117 Using Tidal Deformation Signatures for Gravitational Wave Cosmography W ith Third Generation Detectors Shreya Anand Mentor: Alex Urban The past detections of Advanced LIGO have shown that current generation detectors have the capability to detect binary black holes at redshifts up to 0.2. Next generation detectors, however, with a factor of 10 increase in sensitivity compared to Advanced LIGO, are predicted to detect even binary neutron star (BNS) and neutron star - black hole (NSBH ) sources to higher redshifts. We analyze a method of performing cosmography with third generation (3G) detectors using gravitational waves from BNS and NSBH inspirals alone. One can relate the distance to a source obtained from the amplitude of the gravitational waves emitted to its redshift by breaking the mass-redshift degeneracy in the signal waveform, using the frequency at which tidal disruption and tidal deformability signatures are visible. In the third generation detector era, we assume that the N S equation- of-state is known; we determine the measurability of these tidal signatures for different values of the tidal parameter, $\Lambda$, a proxy for the compactness of the star. Using waveform approximants that are valid in both inspiral and postmerg er regimes to simulate NSBH and BNS waveforms with matter effects, we whiten the advanced LIGO data stream, inject the BNS and NSBH signals into the data stream, and attempt to recover tidal deformability signatures for both types of systems. Then, we reco lor the current generation data stream using the modeled noise spectra for the next generation detectors Einstein Telescope and Cosmic Explorer. We determine how well tidal signatures can be recovered for systems of different mass, spin and tidal parameter s, and use this to determine placement of calibr 0ation lines in the sensitivity bands of current and next generation detectors. We aim to provide useful information for setting the calibration requirements for future 3G detector so that cosmography with gravitational waves alone will be possible. Investigation of the Impact of Seismic Noise on LIGO Interferometer Performance Rachel Brodsky Mentors: Thomas Massinger and Jessica The purpose of the LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational -wave Observatory) Scientific Collaboration is to detect gravitational waves as predicted by Einstein's Theory of General Relativity. According to this theory, the acceleration of asymmetric matter results in small perturbations in space -time due to a changing gravitational field. These distortions, called gravitational waves, can be detected with a network of highly sensitive laser interferometers. However, due to this sensitivity the detectors ar e greatly affected by changes in the environment, such as ground motion, lightning strikes, storms, and other forms of inevitable seismic noise. Transient bursts of noise affect the ability of the detectors to recover signals. Using pyCBC software, we inve stigated the changing sensitivity of the detectors during periods of elevated seismic noise, ranging from 200nm/s to 700nm/s earthquake band ground motion. We found that changes in detector sensitivity to binary neutron star (BNS) waveforms differed from t hat to binary black hole (BBH) and black hole neutron star (NSBH) waveforms, and we analyzed types of detector noise which might be causing this decrease in sensitivity. Towards a Fast Frequency -Domain Waveform Model for Kicked Black Hole Binaries Katie Chamberlain Mentors: Davide Gerosa and Rhondale Tso Generic black hole binaries emit gravitational waves anisotropically due to mass and spin asymmetries. The gravitational waves carry linear momentum away from the binary in a preferential direction that causes the binary to recoil during the late inspiral and merger phases of evolution. The black hole recoil (or kick) results in emitted gravitational waves that are Doppler shifted during merger -ringdown as a function of the kick velocity. Gravitational wave observations of such a Doppler shift will allow for the first direct detections of black hole kicks from a binary coalescence. We extend existing phenomenological analytic frequency -domain gravitational waveform approximants to model gravitational waves from a kicked back hole binary. Our kicked frequency - domain model is quick to calculate and can be used to (i) explore kick detectability over large regions of parameter space, (ii) address degeneracies that are present between kicks and other binary parameters, and (iii) place projected constraints on black hole kick velocities with current and future detectors. Electromagnetic Counterparts of Advanced LIGO Binary Black Hole Merger Events Cierra Coughlin Mentor: Alex Urban The Advanced LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory) detectors have successfully detected gravitational wave signals from four binary black hole (BBH) mergers, GW150914, LVT1 51012, GW151226, and GW170104. These discoveries have prompted follow -up campaigns to se arch for any electromagnetic (EM) counterparts to the gravitational wave transients, which hav e yielded no strong candidates except for the detection of a weak gamma ray transient 0.4 seconds after GW150914 in the sky localization of this gravitational wav e event. Our motivation for this project is therefore to study various models of binary black hole mergers to predict whether or not any EM emission should be expected, and if so, what kind, how much, and when. While we 118 currently do not believe that BBH me rgers produce EM counterparts, the results of this study will help assess the prospects of these campaigns given our current observing limitations and will ultimately be an important step forward for future work in multimessenger astronomy. Squeezing Quan tum Noise With Waveguides Dhruva Ganapathy Mentor: Andrew Wade The LIGO gravitational wave detectors use a modified version of the Michelson Interferometer designed to detect strain signals in the order of a few parts in 10^ -24. The vacuum fluctuations e ntering interferometer through the antisymmetric port are the origin of shot noise in the gravitational wave channel that limits the design sensitivity over most of the detection band. Squeezing entails preparing a special quantum state of light where for a pair of non-commuting observables, such as phase and amplitude of a light state, most of the uncertainty is reduced in only one of the variables (phase or amplitude) at the expense of the other. The aims is to convert vacuum to squeezed vacuum, which ha s phase fluctuations smaller than normal vacuum. Currently, free space optical parametric oscillator squeezers are being integrated into Advanced LIGO, with a goal of a 6 dB reduction in quantum noise. Squeezing is reduced by losses caused imperfections in optical surfaces, substrates and polarizing optics, and, by imperfect spatial overlap with the interferometer fields. In this project, we attempt to make an alternative type of squeezer in a waveguide rather than free space cavity enhanced non- linear devi ces and that offer to simplify operation and eliminate some sources of noise that affect free space squeezing. We will be using a rubidium infused PPTKP waveguide as our source of squeezed light. By the end of this project, we hope to demonstrate its opera tion as a source of continuous wave squeezed states and evaluate its viability as an alternative technology for enhancing the quantum noise performance of future gravitational wave detectors Characterizing Bulk Scatter in Crystalline Silicon Amani M. Garvin Mentor: Andrew Wade In current gravitational wave detectors, coating and substrate Brownian noise dominate around 10Hz. This noise depends on the material's temperature, so in order to decrease this noise cryogenic temperatures are projected to be used. However, fused silica, which is currently used as the mirror's substrate and test masses, has high mechanical losses at cryogenic temperatures. In order to decrease the detector's Brownian noise efficiently, we must change the substrate material. Cry stalline Silicon is a great proponent due to its low mechanical loss at low temperature, however its optical properties have to be investigated. The scope of this work is to characterize the scatter in Magnetic field -grown Michael Czochralski silicon. Scatter from the materials in the detector can add phase noise, contribute to cavity loss, and disrupt squeeze states. In order to analyze scatter from silicon, a motorized scatterometer was built to measure the scattered field. Since Rayleigh scattering is ex pected, that is explored here in order to be compared to the results. cWB Optimization for GW Signal Waveform Reconstruction Stage Yanqi Gu Mentor: Sharon Brunet GW signal Wave Reconstruction has been profiled as a highly CPU intensive and time -consuming step in the cWB pipeline. The aim of this project is to give deeper profile of the time costs of cWB pipeline, understand and address cause(s) for the likelihood WP section of CWB which is most time consuming, and find a probable candidate for porting to execution on a GPU and Many Integrated Core (MIC) architecture, using a specified collection of parameters (input configuration) specified by the code developers. The optimization focuses on: 1) use a many core system to run the likelihood WP in parallel 2) port the time -consuming code to GPU for specific parallelization 3) optimize the data structure of reconstruction for parallel access. Deep Learning for Gravitational Wave Searches Sarah Hale Mentor: Rory Smith Currently gravitational wave signals are detected by matched filtering using data from the main astrophysical data channels. Unfortunately, there are transient sources of noise which limit the effectiveness of this method, so many signals of moderate SNR cannot be classified for sure as true signals or n ot using just the astrophysical channels. We expect to be able to improve upon this by incorporating other auxiliary data channels which inform us about environmental noise, which could correlate with transient noise in the astrophysical channel. These noi se sources are coupled to the detector nonlinearly, so modeling their effect on the detector's noise from fundamentals is difficult and not practical. Instead, we propose to use deep learning. A well trained neural network could potentially learn how envir onmental noise affects the detector without a priori knowledge of how the noise couples with the detector. This project will investigate how deep learning can help differentiate signals from transient noise using well chosen auxiliary channels, potentially outperforming current matched filter searches. 119 Temperature Control and Coupled Oscillator Modelling for LIGO Voyager Jordan T. Kemp 2022, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational -Wave Observatory (LIGO) project will undergo its transition from its third iteration, A+, to its fourth iteration, Voyager. LIGO Voyager intends to reduce coating thermal noise by operating LIGO at cryogenic temperatures and replacing fused silica optics with silicon. My summer research with the Voyager group addressed the cooling of the planned thermal shields surrounding the LIGO optics using copper straps, the parameter optimization of a ringdown experiment to determine the loss of optics coatings, and determining the temperature dependence of the eigenfrequencies of bulk silicon to develop a method of decoupled temperature determination. Our findings suggest that the F designated copper straps cool more eff iciently than S and L straps with a thermal conductivity constant of .06721 ±.0009W/K . We have produced an approximation of the error budget for the ringdown measurement which suggests that the uncertainty in the loss angle of the disk and coupled system most strongly influences the error in our loss measurement, and precise measurement of these parameters will result in the most precise results . We have also produced an apparatus for calibrating the temperature dependence of the eigenfrequencies of silicon disks. Development of Remote Controls for the Motorized Polarization Controller in LIGO's Arm Length Stabilization System Caroline Martin Mentor: Daniel Sigg The arm length stabilization (ALS) system allows the arms of the interferometer to be locked separately, decoupling these two degrees of freedom from the Fabry -Perot and recycling cavities; this system faces issues with polarization drift along fiber optic cables, however, due to factors such as thermal stress, mechanical stress, and irregulariti es in the shape of the core. If this drift is not corrected, the mismatch in polarization can prevent the interferometer from observing.
