Currently, this drift is corrected by a motorized polarization controller (MPC) that must be adjusted manually on a reg ular basis. This project aims to develop comprehensive, user -friendly, and robust remote controls for the polarization controller to streamline the drift correction. The controller was connected through a serial port to TwinCAT Programmable Logic Controlle r software, on which the controls were written in IEC -1131 structured text. User input through a graphic interface is interpreted and written to this code, allowing the user to remotely control the polarization. In the future, this program could be used to automate the correction process. Testing General Relativity W ith Binary Black Hole Mergers Radha Mastandrea Mentor: Alan Weinstein The several recent detections of gravitational waves (GWs) by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational -Wave Observatory (LIG O) has provided researchers with the first opportunities to test general relativity (GR) in the strong -field and highly -dynamical limit. Qualitative tests of the agreement between LIGO's GW observations and classical GR have already been done; we aim to ca rry out more quantitative tests in terms of controlled, parameterized deviations from GR. In this project, we run a matched -filter analysis on LIGO's prior detections using templates with known amplitude and frequency deviations from those predicted by GR to a construct a probability function on the deviations. We then simulate a number of BBH merger waveforms with similar deviations from GR, use Bayesian analysis to recover the deviation, and provide an estimate of the number of GW detections from BBH merg ers necessary to establish a given deviation from classical GR. GeNS and Electrostatic Suspension Systems Mariia Matiushechkina Mentor: Brittany Kamai The third generation of interferometric gravitational wave detectors will use silicon test masses and silicon suspension systems kept at low temperature (123K). For this reason it is important to find the appropriate high- emissivity coating to cool the detectors' test masses and the high -reflectivity dielectric coating so both introduce the lowest additional thermal noise. The project includes the characterization of the Gentle Nodal suspension (GeNS) experimental set- up for measuring mechanical loss angle of the thin film coatings on silicon at cryogenic temperature and developing for future precision experiments a new low -loss suspension system that uses electrostatic field to levitate a disk without mechanical contacts . The second part consists of designi ng the Printed Circuit Board of the electrode pattern, assembling the set- up and optimizing its parameters with finite element modeling (FEM) software like COMSOL Multiphysics. The aim is to compare noise that appears due to GeNS and electrostatic suspensi on systems. This project will help to conduct higher -precision loss measurements of test masses for future development of gravitational wave detectors. 120 Determining Remnant Parameters From Black -Hole Binary Systems Nicholas Meyer Mentor: Mark Scheel Computing the remnant mass, spin, and recoil of a black hole binary in principle requires numerical relativity (NR) simulations. Unfortunately, NR simulations cannot be performed quickly enough for some waveform models and LIGO data analysis routines that require remnant parameters. We develop phenomenological formulae for the remnant mass, spin, and recoil of binary systems given arbitrary initial spins and mass ratios. We do this by constructing fits to NR simulations in the SXS catalog. In particular, we explore the use of Gaussian Process Regression. We use the SXS catalog to compare the accuracy of our remnant mass and spin fits with that of the remnant mass and spin formulae in the Effective One Body (EOB) waveform model in the LSC Algorithm Library Gautam and Johannes light in LIGO has dual demerits, firstly this scattered light can reflect off other objects in the setup and couple back into the instrument, adding noise and secondly, the light power that is lost to scattering leads to a lower signal -to-noise ratio in the interferometer. Therefore, in order to increase aLIGO's sensitivity to gravitational waves, light scattering must be r educed. As a part of the laser beam scatters or deviates from the path governed by specular reflection, on account of roughness of the test mass surfaces and instead of yielding a coherent, collimated beam, the intensity pattern becomes angle dependent. This is modeled by the Bidirectional Reflection Distribution function (BRDF). The project aims to install, interface with and calibrate Gigabit Ethernet cameras to image the test masses, obtain the BRDF for light scattering at the test mass and identify point -scatterers in the images of test masses through the techniques of aperture photometry. These measurements could be used to quantify scatter loss and identify measures to minimize this loss. Inferring the Astrophysical Population of Black Hole Binaries Osase Omoruyi Mentor: Alan Weinstein LIGO's gravitational wave detections have not only proved the existence of black hole binaries but also confirmed the presence of stellar mass black holes larger than 20 solar masses. Our project aims to study these binaries and their mass distribution thr oughout space. Currently, LIGO has made 4 detections of binary black hole mergers. However, this sample is too small to draw significant conclusions about the mass distribution. To circumvent this problem, our project looks towards the future. Within the next 10 years, LIGO expects the number detections to rise significantly. With these future detections in mind, our project utilizes simulated data to generate a large population of black hole binaries. From our general astrophysical knowledge about black ho les and nature, we expect the underlying population to fall like a power -law in the mass of the larger black hole, M -, in which is the power -law index. Using the large sample of events our simulations provide, we seek to constrain the value of the power -law index more precisely and accurately. This, in turn, will allow us to make inferences about how black hole binaries have formed and evolved over time. Measuring Optical Scattering Off LIGO Test Masses Christian Pluchar Mentor: Keita Kawabe The LIGO interferometers utilize precisely manufactured test masses made of silica glass in order to detect the small displacements due to gravitational waves. A number of optical techniques are used to increase the laser power circulating in the detector into the kilowatt range, including Fabry -Perot cavities and power recycling, increasing sensitivity. Optical scattering off the test masses introduce noise into the detector output and reduce the amount of light in the resonant cavities of the interferometer, reducing sensitivity. The power of the light scattered off the test mass by the main laser was measured using high resolution digital camera sensors, allowing for more detailed measurement of the LIGO Hanford test masses. Two DSLR cameras were calibrated to find the relationship between the power of light incident on the sensor and the digital output of the camera. While the interferometer was locked, a series of images were captured at different exposure times. Using the calibration of the camera and information on the placement of the Photon Calibrator (Pcal) cameras used, an estimate of the power scattered by the test masses was calculated. To further characterize the camera sensor performance, the photon absorption rate of the camera was measured. 121 Online Detector Characterization U sing Neural Networks obtained from LIGO has noise that comes from many sources. To be able to better distinguish signals from the noise, it is important to characterize the type of noise observed. Machine learning algorithms can be used to look for patterns within the data and to classify the data into distinct categories . We are using clustering algorithms , such as kmeans, to identify earthquakes in seismic noise data. To test how well the clustering algorithms work, we comp are the clusters to the times when earthquake waves reach the detector site. This comparison will be used to evaluate how well a neural network determines earthquake s compared to the clustering algorithms. Optimization of the Coating Ringdown Measurement Laboratory Electrostatic Actuator With Finite Element Modeling Zachary A. Rose Mentor: Gabriele Vajente In aLIGO one of the most substantial displacement noise sources is thermal noise, with the mirror coatings as the dominant source of this noise. The most viable option to limit this noise is producing mirror coatings with a smaller loss angle. The loss angle can be studied by exciting the resonant modes of a sampl e with an electrostatic drive (ESD) and then measuring their exponential decay time, or ringdown. For experimental ease, a 75 mm fused silica disk is used to simulate the LIGO test mass. To improve accuracy, it is important that the electrostatic actuator excites all of the fundamental modes of the sample as much as possible. The goal of my project was to determine the optimal shape of the actuator to drive all of the fundamental vibrational modes maximally. I accomplished this by modeling the current ESD in COMSOL, a finite element modeling software. Then I wrote scripts in MATLAB to iteratively sweep through various spatial parameters to determine the optimal geometry. Finally, I tried some non- standard geometries to determine the best design. RF Leakage Studies and GPS Signal Jitter Analysis John Schaefer Mentor s: Dick Gustafson and Keita Kawabe RF signals are mainly responsible for putting the interferometer into lock, an important task that allows LIGO to be sensitive enough for gravitational events. However, RF signals can cause leakage that can interfere with other electronics. One culprit is DC ground isolation units. When performing a spectrum analysis using an RF analyzer and measuring cabling ground to cabling ground, it was found that there were significant signal leakages as high as ~80 mV when it should ideally be 1 mV. Upon investigatio n and testing, it was determined that the leakages were due to small or absent capacitance along the units' enclosures. After modifying the capacitance of the units and then testing for insertion loss and phase delay, an order of magnitude decrease in RF l eakage was observed. Timing, from both GPS and a cesium clock, is another important aspect of LIGO which dictates much of how measurements are taken. When several atomic clocks are tuned to be in phase with each other and triggered on a 1 PPS GPS signal, the clock signals jitter on the order of nanoseconds. Given that this is tested against multiple clocks, GPS must be the source of the jitters. This may not have a large effect on short term measurements, but for long term integrations such as continuous wa ve searches, this error may become a problem. After long term data acquisition and analysis, it was found there were distinct periodicities in the jitter. Further analysis was also done to determine whether these jitters were random or deterministic. Characteriza tion of Angular Noise Coupling I nto Differential Arm Length of the LIGO Livingston Detector Brian C. Seymour Mentors: of the Fabry Perot Cavity mirrors can change the cavity length. This source of noise can couple into differential arm length of a gravitational wave detector. This paper explores length change due to angular misalignment, and then extends it to the effect of angular noise on the two cavity system. We will also provide results from an experiment where we use mechanical modulation to measure the main angular components that are believed to couple most strongly to the differential arm length. The angular noise coupling mo del and experimental results will be used in combination to understand the angular noise contribution to differential arm length noise. Mode Spectroscopy for Mirror Metrology Kaustubh Singhi Mentor: Koji Arai The mirrors in the LIGO detectors are not id eal, and have imperfections due to various reasons such as manufacturing defects, thermal defects, etc. These imperfections introduce a total loss in the light resonating inside the cavity arms of the interferometer and thus have to be budgeted in the tota l budget loss. The total loss in aLIGO 122 is estimated at ~100ppm out of which ~20 ppm is budgeted for the mirror imperfections, more commonly called the mirror figure error. It is the second highest contributor to the total intensity loss and hence it is sig nificantly important to be able to characterize this loss. Mode Spectroscopy is something that we will be using to do this. We will do our experimentation on the 40m prototype, which is quite similar to the aLIGO. We will scan the cavity for various 'Highe r Order Modes' and compare our results with the ideally expected values. Using this data, we will try and produce a mirror map telling us what are the defects in the mirror and how much is the total cavity loss due to the mirror figure error. Implementing Real-Time Calibration in Advanced LIGO Control Software Dane W. Stocks Mentor: Joseph Betzwieser The digital error and control signals of Advanced LIGO's differential arm length control servo are used to reconstruct gravitational wave (GW) strain, h(t). Currently, three different calibration pipelines produce h(t) with varying errors and latencies. The real -time operating system in the front end computers runs CALCS, which performs infinite impulse response (IIR) filtering and control operations on 16 384 Hz clock cycles. Current limitations of these filters yield systematic errors which a second pipeline, the GDS, corrects in low -latency using finite impulse response (FIR) filtering on computers distinct from the front end computers. The third pipeline , the DCS, implements FIR filtering to condition archived data, and is used to recalibrate entire data sets when dropouts occur in real -time. To prepare for O3 in late 2018, we construct a new, self -contained calibration pipeline in the front end computers which uses FIR filtering to calculate h(t). This new front end model will replace the current calibration system in place, removing the redundancy of multiple, separate pipelines while reducing latency in control room access to calibrated GW strain. the Advanced LIGO detectors, the coating Brownian noise is expected to be the largest of the thermal noise sources at their most sensitive frequency band. The LIGO Voyager upgrade aims to reduce this thermal noise by operating the optics at cryogenic temperatures and replacing fused silica test masses with silicon. In ord er to characterize Brownian noise in the candidate coatings on silicon mirrors, two similar optical cavities which are dominated by coating Brownian noise are used in a differential measurement. Two independent lasers are locked to the cavities which are then interfered to produce a beat signal, whose frequency noise represents the differential length fluctuations due to coating Brownian noise. An All Digital Phase Lock Loop(ADPLL) was designed and implemented in a Field Programmable Gate Array(FPGA) on a Red Pitaya board, to demodulate the frequency information from the beat note and pass it on to the Data Acquisition system. Based on the input noise measurements of the Analog to Digital Converter, the required readout noise of 1mHz/sqrt(Hz) from 10Hz to 1 0kHz can be achieved. The ADPLL comprises of a Numerically Controlled Oscillator(NCO) which is locked to the input signal, two digital IIR low pass filters in cascade and a PI controller as a servo for the frequency readout. Several compression techniques were used to reduce the size of Look -Up Tables in the NCO, due to the limited availability of ROM. Laser Spectroscopy for Mirror Metrology Naomi Wharton Mentors: Koji Arai and gravitational wave detectors are specialized Michelson interferometers each with two arms that are four kilometers in length. Each arm of the interferometers forms an optical cavity capped by semi -transparent mirrors by which laser light is transmitted and reflected. Imperfections on the surfaces of these mirrors cause optical power losses in the cavities that must be minimized for optimal performance. In a cavity with perfectly spherical mirrors, the modes of a Gaussian beam will resonate at equally spaced frequencies. In reality, surface perturbatio ns cause the resonance peaks of several higher -order (Hermite -Gaussian) modes to shift in the cavity transmission spectrum. The aim of this project is to use cavity scan techniques to measure deviations in the spacing of these higher -order modes. By compar ing these experimental deviations with theoretical mode spacings, we can learn about the physical properties of the cavity mirrors. Our ultimate goal is to use Bayesian inference techniques to recreate the surface perturbation map of a mirror from its cavi ty transmission spectrum. In-Vacuum Heat Wipf and Johannes a design concept for a cryogenic interferometric detector that aims to reduce the thermal noise in the mirrors by switching to crystalline silicon substrates and operating at 123K. A clamping mechanism is being designed that can attach to the mirrors to provide fast and efficient cooling, and then be released during operation to prevent coupling seismic noise to t he system. Studying the rate of heat transfer across the interface between 123 polished silicon and the contacting surface of a potential heat switch mechanism is important research for this project . By creating a temperature gradient inside a cryostat with a known amount of injected heat and measuring the temperatures on both sides of the interface, it is possible to determine the heat flow. This method was used investigate how the thermal heat transfer of the interface changes depending on contact pressure and surface quality. The set up was also used to investigate the heat flow across optically bonded silicon pieces to evaluate the effectiveness of different curing strategies post -initial contact. Jet Propulsion Laboratory J P L JPL 127 Development of a Database Tool Used to Support Planetary fornia Institute of Technology One of the objectives of the Planetary Protection discipline is to prevent microbial contamination of other planets through space travel, and to protect Earth's biosphere from extraterrestrial contamination through sample return. On missions such as Mars 2020, part of the verification, validati on and certification process includes the monitoring of spacecraft surfaces by conducting bioassays to measure the physical bioburden of each surface. Samples are taken directly from hardware and exposed to the NASA standard spore assay, and all associated metadata is then stored within a laboratory information management system (e.g. database / barcode program). This grassroots database, designed in 2003, and housed in Microsoft Access, no longer reflects the state of the art, and could be updated for bett er maintenance and management. A future goal for the project will be to completely redesign the database. However, given the demanding timeline for Mars 2020 and technicalities of transferring data properly, it is currently more practical to address the im mediate issues of the program to ensure data integrity for the remainder of the mission. My research has thus involved designing features within the barcode program to standardize data input, include data verification, improve the user interface, and fix b roken modules. These features will lead to easier access of the program for Mars 2020 assays, and lay a more modern foundation for future developments. Phase Curve Analysis of Super -Earth 55 Cancri e Isabel Angelo Mentor: Renyu Hu, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology One of the primary questions when characterizing Earth- sized and super -Earth -sized exoplanets is whether they have a substantial atmosphere like Earth and Venus, or a bare -rock surface that may come with a te nuous atmosphere like Mercury. Phase curves of the planets in thermal emission provide clues to this question, because a substantial atmosphere would transport heat more efficiently than a bare -rock surface. Analyzing phase curve photometric data around se condary eclipse has previously been used to study energy transport in the atmospheres of hot Jupiters. Here we use phase curve, Spitzer time-series photometry to study the thermal emission properties of the super -Earth exoplanet 55 Cancri e. We utilize a p reviously developed semi -analytical framework to fit a physical model to infrared photometric data of host star 55 Cancri from the S pitzer telescope IRAC 2 band at 4.5 m. The model uses various parameters of planetary properties including Bond albedo, hea t redistribution efficiency (i.e., the ratio between the radiative timescale and advective timescale of the photosphere), and atmospheric greenhouse factor. The phase curve of 55 Cancri e is dominated by thermal emission with an eastward -shifted hot spot l ocated on the planet surface. We determine the heat redistribution efficiency to be 1.47, which implies that the advective timescale is on the same order as the radiative timescale. This requirement from the phase curve cannot be met by the bare -rock plan et scenario, because heat transport by currents of molten lava would be too slow. The phase curve thus favors the scenario with a substantial atmosphere. Our constraints on the heat redistribution efficiency translate to a photosphere pressure of ~1.4 bar. The Spitzer IRAC 2 band is thus a window into the deep atmosphere of the planet 55 Cancri e. A New M etagenomics Pipeline Developed From Open-Source Computational Tools for Mars and ISS Missions Roshni Biswas of Technology, Rourkela ) Mentors: Kasthuri J. Venkateswaran, Nitin K. Singh, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technolog y Culture -independent approaches coupled with computational techniques will provide new insights to comprehensively characterize functional pro perties of microorganisms, their interactions with the environment, hosts, and infectious disease -causing potential in the spaceflight environment. The developed pipeline focuses on characterizing microbes and their functions by performing trimming and quality filtering, assembly, annotation, and profiling. The entire pipeline is executable on a normal computer or laptop and does not require a supercomputer configuratio n. This simplified metagenomics pipeline is rapid (reduces months to days for 500 GB data) and is useful for planetary protection engineers and astrobiologists who are not experienced with computational skills. 128 Electric Thruster Plume Instrumentation and Integration Owen Burek, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Mentor: Lee K. Johnson, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Electric propulsion is a rising tide in the field of interstellar exploration b ecause it can propel satellites and probes vast distances using charged particles as the exhaust. The thrusters ionize noble gas from electron collisions which are then ejected out using an electric field. Our work involves implementing two devices, the Ex B and ESA probes, used to measure diagnostic properties of the plume such as the energies of the particles and the charge species. We designed configurations to mount the probes in the chamber using CAD modeling software which we then created using various machining techniques. The LabVIEW software we created controls the apparatus inside the chamber to adjust its position and orientation to collect data from the modules. By the end of the research period we will be able measure the plume energy and charge distribution using a single integrated device which will help us understand the thruster performance and char acteristics. Implementation and Assessment of Convolutional Neural Networks as Efficient Emulators for Atmospheric Models Berlin Chen (Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology) Mentors: Hai Nguyen and Derek Posselt This project is a ten -week effort to implement and assess Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) as efficient emulators for atmospheric models. To produce reliable weather forecasts, one would need to effectively calibrate models using sensitivity analysis; however, conventional methods are often computationally costly. Using CNNs as emulators, we are able to bypass solving the partial -differential equations (PDEs) explicitly, thus cutting down the computational cost. Training the CNN is done on a per -unit ba sis in the vertical dimension, with inputs being the minimal information needed to approximate second -order PDEs. We trained the CNN on multiple time intervals and tested the CNN's ability to generalize by assessing the CNN's prediction accuracy. The CNN p erformed well in predicting one time step within the training data, getting an error of less than 0.3 percent on water -vapor data at around 935 hPa. Further work is needed to better assess the CNN's performance, which can be done by collecting data of the CNN predicting multiple time steps beyond the training data, and by analyzing the CNN's performance as a function of the CNN's input variables. Digitizing Smoke Plumes: The Multi -Angle and Tosca2 1Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology 2School of the Art Institute of Chicago The Multi -Angle Imaging SpectroRadiometer is a satellite instrument that captures images of Earth from nine different angles. The instrument's stereoscopic observations allow scientists to obtain the heights of smoke plumes. However, plumes must be digitized by a human technician to determine hei ght data. Therefore, the Multi -Angle Imaging SpectroRadiometer Plume Height Project compiles data from years of plume digitization efforts. The objective of the summer 2017 segment of this project is to augment the database by digitizing plumes from Januar y to June of 2011. To fulfill this objective, plumes are digitized using the Multi -Angle Imaging SpectroRadiometer INteractive eXplorer; technicians correct misregistration, then isolate each smoke plume and indicate the wind direction. With plumes from the specified time period successfully digitized, the resulting data can be used in aerosol, climate change, and air quality studies. Ultimately, the data may also be used in training computers to automate the plume digitization process. Using [CII] to Char acterize Star Formation in M51 Luiza Coelho, California Institute of Technology Mentor: Jorge L. Pineda, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology The [CII] 157.7 micron line is the brightest spectral line emitted from the interstellar medium (ISM) at far -infrared wavelengths, and is a main coolant of the neutral ISM in diffuse clouds. With the advent of stratospheric observation, [CII] line emission is significantly easier to trace than CO, and has been observed in multiple phases of the ISM. Here we compared various tracers of star formation, including the total infrared emission, far - ultraviolet emission, H -alpha, and radio continuum emission with [CII] line emission observations from SOFIA. We find that [CII] emission is directly related to star formation and is strongest in the spiral arms and interarm regions. There is compelling evidence of [CII] suppression in regions of high X -ray activity, as [CII] emission was low in companion galaxy NGC 5195 compared to most other tracers. [CII] could be especially useful when regions high in X -ray activity have low rates of newly forming stars. These findings are highly significant in understanding star for mation in galaxies with strong spiral structure and high OB star formation rates. 129 Atmospheric Correction U sing Deep Neural Networks Shubhankar V. Deshpande, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Mentor: David R. Thompson An open problem in imaging spectroscopy is generating an accurate model of the atmosphere. Physical properties of the atmosphere cannot be directly modeled, and hence this becomes an inverse problem, where a proxy quantity is measured, to derive atmospheric prope rties. The optical effects are captured within the radiative transfer equation (RTE), solving of which entails constraining the boundary conditions captured as an initial state vector. Optimal Estimation is a method used for the inverse problem of retrievi ng an accurate state vector. However, a major hurdle is the computational cost associated with running the forward model numerous times. Under certain assumptions, using the universal approximation theorem, we may approximate this continuous function using a multilayer perceptron. We simulate data to generate a high- dimensional parameter space, which is run through the forward model (RTE) to synthesize radiance values, which are decomposed to generate a simpler model. Our model reproduces the mapping to within numerical precision after being trained using state of the art deep learning techniques resulting in a multi -fold speedup. Further, we designed an automated system to track the data product flow at process level granularity. This consolidated system re sults in a streamlined pipeline, reducing the time to generate scientific results. Long -Term Variability of Saturn's Atmosphere as Imaged in the Near Infrared Kenny Duran, California Institute of Technology Mentor: Glenn Orton, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Saturn's spectrum at 5.1 - 5.2 microns arises from thermal emission. Because this radiance is minimally affected by gaseous absorption, images in this wavelength range allow us to peer deep into Saturn's cloud structure to examine the dynamics of its atmosphere. In order to analyze these images, they must be reduced so as to minimize noise due to the telescope and observing conditions such as rapidly fluctuating sky emission, and they must be calibrated radiometrically so as to assign brightness values that correspond with physical radiance values. Calibration was done by scaling the average radiance of an uncalibrated planet image to a calibrated image's average. The radiance at the central meridian for certain latitudes possibly exhibits an increasing then decreasing trend between 25 and 55 degrees latitude, but this trend could appear due to error and further investigation is needed to decipher this. We expect a substantial perturbation of this trend at a time when Satur n's great storm on the Northern hemisphere disrupted the atmospheric composition, temperature and cloud structure in that hemisphere, A significant component of 5.1/5.2 -micron radiation is contributed from reflected sunlight. In order to assess this contri bution, we will reduce and calibrate observations at 1.58 microns, which has similar minimal gaseous absorption but consists completely of reflected sunlight. Optimizing Communications D uring Spacecraft Critical Events for Future Missions Shweta Dutta , California Institute of Technology Mentor: Melissa Soriano, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology When attempting to land on a planetary body, perform a complex direction change, or even while simply cruising, challenges arise in spacecraft to Earth communications. Entry, descent, and landing (EDL) on planetary bodies involves spacecraft undergoing periods of high acceleration and jerk, while orbit insertion involves precise amounts of acceleration and deceleration, and all this increased motion makes for Doppler dynamics. In order to keep track of the spacecraft throughout the increased dynamics of such maneuvers, it is imperative to use communication methods that have a low probability of failing to detect the actual transmitted s ignal This study will first summarize the mechanism to predict the probability of failing to detect the carrier frequency and data tones used in Multiple Frequency -shift Keying (MFSK) by the spacecraft, and then explore the applicability of MFSK in future missions for events including but not limited to EDL, orbit insertion, and cruising. MSFK, or tones, allowed for communication with planetary landers and other spacecraft in the past, namely the Mars Exploration Rover (MER), Mars Science Laboratory (MSL), both primarily for EDL, and Juno for orbit insertion. We also explore possible modifications to the current MFSK method, such as using two or three tones in a time sequence as opposed to one tone per second to expand the vocabulary of information possible to provide, or placing multiple subcarriers on the carrier to again convey a broader scope of information. We study the optimal use of these methods during spacecraft events at different distances from the Earth, because as distance increases, the signal - to-noise ratio (SNR) decreases, making the probability of failing to detect the signal increase, a concern for missions traveling beyond Mars. Using the search space, integration time, fast Fourier Transform (FFT) bandwidth, and modulation index, one may p lot the predicted probability of failing to detect a (carrier or tone) frequency versus the (carrier or tone to) noise ratio . 130 Following the models outlined in Satorius, E., et. al., we demonstrate the probability of failing to detect a carrier or tone d uring EDL to be less than 1% under worst- case expected operating conditions for the Mars 2020 mission, with the lowest chance for error when the craft is cruising, and highest during parachute deployment where the spacecraft motion is uneven. We also exami ne the optimal use of tones during other spacecraft critical events which deal with high dynamics via examination of modifications to MFSK, and comparing how these modifications perform compared to the original technique at different distances from the Ear th. Augmenting the Atmospheric Correction Routine for Imaging Spectrometer PRISM Michelle Fan, California Institute of Technology Mentor s: Justin Haag, David Thompson JPL's Portable Remote Imaging Spectrometer (PRISM) collects spectral and spatial inform ation about the Earth's surface by measuring emitted electromagnetic radiation in the 350 -1050 nm wavelength range. Equipped with a spectrometer, radiometer, and an INS/GPS for geolocation, PRISM surveys areas of interest at altitudes of around 28,000 feet . It is possible to construct a precise reflectance map of the sensed area for various environmental assessment purposes after correcting for interference caused by atmospheric constituents present between the airborne instrument and the ground. The radiance data are processed by the Second Simulation of a Satellite Signal in the Solar Spectrum (6S) code, an atmospheric removal routine which models the gaseous absorption and scattering of radiation under a variety of geometric, atmospheric, spectral, and other environmental parameters. However, our current approach does not account for instrument zenith and azimuth viewing angles, instead assuming that rays exit the spectrometer at an angle orthogonal to the ground and that their projection onto the horizon is aligned with the north vector. We add these two parameters to the atmospheric correction routine and quantify changes by comparing data processed before and after algorithm modification. Improvements to the estimated reflectance result are evaluated usi ng corresponding ground truth measurements. Information Content Analysis of Reflected Exoplanet Spectra George Filippatos, J et Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Mentor: Renyu Hu Future direct imaging missions such as WFIRST will measure the reflectively of exoplanets at visible wavelengths. Exoplanets imaged will be further away from their parent star than is permitted by current transiting techniques. These cold atmospheres are c onducive of the formation of water and ammonia clouds. We study the ability to characterize atmospheric parameters, metalicity and C/O ratio, based on reflected spectra. The retrievable information from the spectra is quantified via the information content and the retrievable degrees of freedom. We find that the amount of retrievable information is dependent on signal to noise ratio and spectral resolution, with an increase in either resulting in an increase in retrievable information. Additionally the characteristics of the planet, metalicity, C/O ratio and orbital distance, effect the retrievable information as well. This causes the signal to noise required to achieve an acceptable degrees of freedom to vary from 10 -75 depending on the planets properties . At the baseline resolution of WFIRST R=70 and a moderate signal to noise of 25 cold atmospheres topped by ammonia clouds have sufficient retrievable information to determine the metalicity and C/O ratio. For warmer atmospheres topped by water clouds, a h igher signal to noise is required. Mars 2020 Planetary Protection Sampling and Processing Activities Eric Franklin* Mentors: Ryan Hendrickson*, Heidi Aronson*, Arman Seuylemezian* *Jet Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91109 COSPAR Planetary Protection policy supports responsible space exploration through efforts to protect other bodies from biological contamination by Earth life and to take precautions to protect Earth from backward contamination from other planetar y bodies. My project includes various aspects in the sequence of planetary protection activities, from planning for future aseptic assembly and sterilization techniques to direct sampling and verification of cleanliness for spacecraft during the assembly p rocess. My project includes assisting with activities along the biological verification workflow for the Mars 2020 mission. Since the Mars 2020 mission is collecting Martian regolith samples for potential return by a future mission, back planetary protecti on requirements dictate stringent biological contamination requirements for the sample cache system. My project involves not only sampling of spacecraft during assembly to ensure these standards are met, but identification and archiving of spores isolated from the spacecraft and the production of a document outlining the gowning, assembly, and facility requirements for the fabrication of the sample tubes and associated hardware on the rover, which must meet the strictest possible cleanliness standards . This would avoid any possibility of a false positive in any experiment that may attempt to confirm the presence of past or current life on Mars. 131 Supercritical CO2 Extraction of Organics F rom Aqueous Samples Paris Franz, Miami University Mentors: Bryana Henderson and Fang Zhong, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology With future in situ missions to Ocean Worlds now in reach, the development of new instrumentation for the analysis of biomarkers is needed to identify existing or past life. The nature of these worlds requires that the instruments are able to extract, separate, and detect organic compounds from complex matrices, including mixed ice/regolith and seawater. Supercritical fluid extraction using supercritica l carbon dioxide (scCO2) holds great potential for accomplishing these tasks. Supercritical fluids possess the solvating power of a liquid, and have lower viscosities and higher diffusivities, allowing for better penetration of porous materials. Additional ly, the mild conditions required for the critical point of CO2 (73 atm and 31.1°C) may prevent the degradation of sensitive biomolecules, scCO2 does not extract inorganic salts which may not be compatible with many chemical analysis techniques, and scCO2 i s a green solvent that will not contaminate the surrounding environment. We have demonstrated the extraction of an array of free fatty acids of various lengths (C10, C12, C14, C16, C18) from aqueous matrices by using supported liquid extraction (SLE) methodology in conjunction with scCO2 extraction, and quantified the extracted fractions using mass spectrometry. We also demonstrated the extraction and detection of capric acid (C10) from a complex seawater sample. Analysis of Alcove -Channel -Apron Morphologies Within Palma Dune F ield, in the North Polar Region of Mars Nathan Grigsby, Boise State University Mentor: Serina Diniega Channel features within sand dune landslides have been recently observed within the nor th polar region of Mars. Such features are unusual within the north polar erg; however, observations from Palma, a dune field located ~95.4°E 76°N show alcove -apron (AA) morphologies scattered throughout the dune field. In this study, we investigate potential factors that influence the formation of a channel, including the volume being displaced, the height of the dune, and the slope of the lee side of the dune. Using a digital terrain model of Palma, we are a ble to measure the dune height and the slope of the lee side of each dune for each landslide. A comparison of these measurements show a correlation between the dune height at each morphology and the amount of volume being moved downslope. Furthermore , trends exist when considering thedune height and volume for the AA or ACA morphologies. Comparing these factors to the different morphologies can give us a better understanding of how sand particle interactions and overall amount of sand moved may have a role in forming the various types of dune avalanche morphologies on Mars. Heat Inactivation of Embedded Bacillus atrophaeus ATCC Spores Ohannes Vahe Guerbidjian, California State University, Northridge Mentor: Wayne Schubert, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Microorganisms are difficult to exclude from materials and when entrapped are known as embedded bioburden. The elimination of embedded bioburden is important for materials to be used in spacec raft parts. Bacterial spores are particularly resistant to inactivation by the application of heat. Spore formers, such as Bacillus atrophaeus ATCC 9372, embedded in epoxy material could be as much as ten -fold more heat resistant than those found on surfac es. Experimentally, spores embedded in epoxy were exposed at elevated temperatures in a silicon oil bath. With a commonly used spacecraft epoxy -adhesive, embedded spores were fully inactivated at 170ºC within 15 minutes. D-values (time to reduce the popula tion by 3 log or 99.9%), for 115ºC was determined as 29.4 hours with the NASA specification value given as 74.6. Values for temperatures of 125 ºC and 135ºC were measured but additional replicates and further statistical treatment are needed. For the 115 º C temperature the results fall within the current specifications NASA has set forth for HMR treatment of bulk materials. Rock Abundance as a Measure of Age in the Lunar Maria James T. Haber (Cornell University) Mentor: Paul Hayne The Moon formed over 4 billion years ago, but its surface has been modified greatly since then by lava flows and through the process of impact cratering. This meteoric bombardment has created a layer of regolith that varies in thickness and rockiness, depe nding on the age of the surface. While the older lunar highlands are all approximately the same age, the lunar maria were formed by lava flows at different times and few have been dated absolutely. Previous studies have used crater counts to estimate the a ges of these regions. This study attempts to find a relation between thermophysical properties, such as rock abundance, and the ages of lava flows within the lunar maria. Our results show that there is a significant negative correlation between rock abunda nce and surface age, which we use to estimate the ages of maria units not previously determined by crater counts. 132 The Zephyrus Missions: A Proof of Concept for Cheap, Reusable, and Modular High- Altitude Balloon Flights Hunter Hall, University of Califo rnia, Berkeley Mentor: Adrian Stoica, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology The Zephyrus Missions are a series of high- altitude balloon (HAB) flight tests conducted by student- researchers in the Innovation to Flight (i2F) program d uring the summer of 2017. The goal of the Zephyrus platform is to create a cheaper and easier -to-use alternative for collecting high- altitude data instead of going through previous JPL HAB systems. There is currently no infrastructure in place for small re search teams and individuals to send up small instruments and collect data from the upper -atmosphere without spending a fortune, and/or large amounts of time developing a new HAB system. While there are many HAB systems at JPL already, most are for larger and more expensive missions that require months to construct. Often times these systems are much too large for the needs of the small research teams and individuals. The Zephyrus platform paves the way for future researchers at JPL to test their small-mid-sized instruments in the upper atmosphere without having to spend large amounts of time and money developing the vehicle that will take their technology to the stratosphere. The Zephyrus HAB system is unique in the fact that it is reusable, relia ble, and modular. This summer, the i2F team has successfully demonstrated all of these key features of the Zephyrus platform via two test flights and a planned third test flight in late August. The Zephyrus I and Zephyrus II were able to be successfully l aunched, tracked, and recovered, all while performing most the science they had set out to accomplish. The errors that were made in the Zephyrus I flight were successfully navigated through during the Zephyrus II flight. Many diverse instruments and exper iments were tested during the Zephyrus Missions, and now the Zephyrus platform is ready to be utilized by others at JPL for their own flight- tests. Mapping Saturn's Hydrocarbons and Haze From Cassini Juliette Hu (Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology) Mentors: Robert West and Scott Edgington (Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology) Cassini has been in orbit around Saturn since 2004, collecting a wealth of observations about the Saturnian system. It is of inte rest to model Saturn's atmosphere to further our understanding of the atmospheric dynamics and photochemistry in the outer solar system. The dominant chemistry in Saturn's upper atmosphere involves hydrocarbons. As the chemical composition cannot be physic ally sampled, we are motivated to study the behavior of hydrocarbons (primarily acetylene) and haze across latitude and time to infer about the atmosphere. We selected observations from the HI -FUV channel of the Ultraviolet Imaging Spectrograph (UVIS) limi ted to Saturn's dayside with minimal ring interference. The data were calibrated in IDL and processed through singular value decomposition (SVD) to isolate key spectral components, which were used to visualize patterns and relationships with phase angle, l atitude, and incidence and emission angles. From SVD analysis, we obtain parameters that can be used with radiative transfer codes to calculate energy transfer through planetary atmospheres. We generate reflectance spectra of a model atmosphere for Saturn and iteratively improve the model by comparing with Cassini data. This work was performed by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology. Sintered Filter Testing for Planetary Protection Emily Klonicki * Mentors: Ryan Hendrickson*, Heidi Aronson* Affiliation: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology* The Planetary Protection group at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory is responsible for determining the bioburden of the Mars 2020 spacecraft . Various components of the Mars 2020 mission use sintered filters , which filter particles from enclosed spacecraft surfaces. The objective of this study is to use flight filters to determine the optimal filter type and size needed to prevent leakage of spores ( 1µm). We develope d a series of filter integrity tests using an instantaneous microbial detection system (BioVigilant), and visualizations by means of fluorescent and SEM imaging to demonstrate the efficiency and particulate leakage of the tested filter. We found that the f ilter has an average efficiency of 99 .8% and percent leakage of 0. 194% of particles 1µm. Furthermore, in comparison to a HEPA filter , the sintered filter is less efficient at particle removal. The 0.4 µm nominal retention sintered filter tested, having a non-uniform media porosity, allowed for particles up to 10µm to breach the filter. These results suggest that a single sintered filter with these specifications may have difficulty preventing spores, or larger biological particles, from passing through the filter. In order to create a first order approximation of Europan conditions, we explore the effects of various concentrations of magn esium sulfate on ice morphology under medium vacuum below 0 °C. At concentrations above 0.4 M (created at room temperature), freezing a Magnesium Sulfate solution results in a salt crust atop the solution and minimal to no excavation of ice underneath. As we have observed spiked ice form ations with deionized water ice tests using the same procedure, we expect that at lower concentrations, the formation of ice spires, known as penitentes, or penitente -like structures will occur, as that would cover the phase space between deionized water ice and the salt solution ice. Photobombs and Mars Meteorites: Detecting and E xplaining Unexpected Image Content Jake Lee , Columbia University & Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Mentors: Kiri Wagstaff and Umaa Rebbapragada The scientific discovery process relies on the ability of researchers to quickly recognize and interpret data with unexpected properties. As the volume and complexity of collected data increases, this process suffers due to limitations in resources. DEMUD was previously developed as a tool to automatically prioritize unexpected data for review, uniquely providing explanations for its prioritizations. While it was demonstrated successfully on one - dimensional data, new strategies were needed to interpret two -dimensional imagery. We have improved DEMUD's imagery interpretation by replacing its original pixel -based representations with feature representations extracted from the fully connected layers of a pre -trained convolutional neural network (CNN). By using these CNN features, DEMUD is able to make more meaningful selections and explanations than when operating on pixels alone. CNN features allow DEMUD to prioritize data based on general and abstract spatial features that researchers can easily understand. Wo rk is ongoing to apply these methods to Mars rover imagery and other planetary imagery in the Planetary Data System database, and we hope to facilitate the scientific discovery process for researchers working with these images. Seasonal Temperature Var iations of Saturn 's Atmosphere F rom Mid- Infrared Observations Zheyu Li, University of Oxford Mentor: Glenn Orton, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology The thermal properties of the Saturnian atmosphere can be studied with mid -infrared images from ground -based telescopes using specific calibration methods.
