The troposphere and stratosphere exhibit seasonal variation in the temperature difference across latitudes, among other phenomena, of which observational data can be compared against the results of theoretical simulations. This gives insight into the observed phenomena as well as provides useful information for refinement of the models. I compare the observed seasonal variation from data gathered over the pas t three decades to the predictions of the latest three - dimensional models of Saturn' s atmosphere: the Outer -Planet General Circulation Model (OPGCM) by Friedson and Moses and the Global Climate Model (GCM) by A. Spiga. Optimal Extraction of Co smological Information From LSST and WFIRST Nora Linzer , California Institute of Technology Mentor: Tim Eifler, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Future missions such as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) and the Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope (WFIRST) will produce enormous amounts of data and provide an unprecedented constraining power on cosmology. These data sets will require a refi ned treatment of systematic uncertainties to extract as much cosmological information as possible. Currently, systematic errors are parameterized individually through "nuisance parameters," an inefficient process as these parameters are often correlated. I n the past, "principal component analysis" (PCA) was used to minimize the number of nuisance parameters for errors caused by baryonic physics. We will extend this method and include other systematic errors including shear calibration, photo -z uncertainties , intrinsic alignment, and galaxy bias. We will test our method in simulated likelihood analyses for WFIRST and LSST, and potentially explore applications to the ongoing analysis of the Dark Energy Survey (DES). 134 Examining the Slope -Sinuosity Relationshi p of Martian Linear Gullies Matthew Maclay, Carleton College, Dept. of Physics and Astronomy Mentor: Serina Diniega Observations with the High Resolution Imaging Science Experiment (HiRISE) camera in the southern mid -latitudes of Mars have identified long and narrow linear gullies which undergo present- day modification due to seasonal frost processes. The leading hypothesis of their formation is sublimating CO2 ice slabs gliding down sandy slopes, carving a track as they go. While this model is consistent with the general morphology and overall downhill direction of linear gullies, it does not yet have a proposed mechanism to explain variations in sinuosity among linear gullies, including regions of extreme sinuosity (S ~1.3). A slope -driven or repeat activ ity driven sinuosity mechanism has been proposed. By constructing and analyzing digital terrain models (DTMs), we examine the local topography of fields which contain both sinuous and non- sinuous linear gullies. We develop a method for identifying sinuous segments within a linear gully, and perform a statistical analysis of the slope distribution of sinuous and non- sinuous gully segments. We present our findings of the relationship between linear gully slope and sinuosity in several fields with our new exte nded DTM coverage on Mars. Guided by our slope -results, we propose hypothesis -driven future work in order to further understand the development and evolution of sinuosity in linear gullies. Modeling Spark Plasma Sintering of Ion Conductors Christopher Mallia , City University of New York, Hunter College Mentor: William West, Electrochemical Technologies Group, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Lithium -ion batteries are the predominate chemistry for rechargeable batteries used in commercial, military and industrial applications. Despite widespread usage, lithium -ion cells inherently possess risks of safety and stability that prevent their usage in many applications. Solid -state lithium battery chemistries present an alternative that do not possess these same risks, but existing solid -state electrolyte materials have shown to be limited in energy density and ionic conductivity, secondary in performance to lithium -ion cells. Dense, low porosity ceramic materials with a high ionic conductivity are of particular interest for usage as electrolytes in solid -state lithium batteries, and are a promising competitor to existing lithium -ion materials. To create such materials, a particular process known as spark plasma sintering (SPS) is of great interest and here is numerically simulated. Computational simulation allows for the exploration SPS potential in creating suitable electrolyte materials. Although widely praised for its capabilities, such as high internal heating rates, the physical process has largely remained only qualitatively understood. This research effort focuses on the development of a fully coupled multiphysics simulation, accounting for SPS parameters and their effects on material behavior. The model aims to predict thermal , electrical and mechanical effects throughout the sintering process. This paper details the framework of a model developed in ABAQUS finite element method (FEM) software, which couples all three physical effects in the analysis, while retaining the neces sary degrees of freedom for the implementation of more precise considerations in future works on specific materials. Enhancement of Robot Sequencing and Visualization Program for Use in Simulation of Robot Sequences Mohith Manohara, California Institute o f Technology Mentor: Steven Myint The Rover Sequencing and Visualization Program (RSVP) is a software used to visualize the movements of spacecraft on Martian terrain. With space missions in the near future, it is necessary to enhance RSVP to ensure that simulated arm and joint movements will accurately reflect the same movements on the robot. One important enhancement for the InSight simulations is to enable a feature that lets an instrument tilt when placed on the ground. Though this feature had existed previously, it caused the instrument would arbitrarily rotate to the robot's orientation when it was grappled, regardless of its initial conditions. To correctly implement this feature, the program first calculated the instrument's orientation on the terra in in the robot's reference frame. Then, the yaw angle was forced back to its initial condition and the pitch and roll angles were corrected to account for this. Another enhancement involves switching build methods from GNU Make to CMake. CMake is more des irable because it works with multiple platforms and it implements parallel builds more easily. These enhancements to RSVP will ensure that future simulations are more accurate and that developers can work on RSVP in different platforms, which will benefit upcoming the space programs. Creating Software for the Assignment of Geometry to the Near -Infrared SpeX Instrument's Scanned Spectroscopic Observations of Jupiter Ziyan Mo, California Institute of Technology Mentor: Glenn S. Orton, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology Quantitative information about Jupiter's chemical, dynamical, and cloud -forming processes that shape its atmosphere can be revealed by investigating its near -infrared spectrum . SpeX is a medium operation at NASA's Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF), and SpeXTools is a piece of software supplied by the IRTF that aids in reducing SpeX data. Past interns have added code to reduce spectra 135 pixel-by-pixel, which was otherwise written to reduce the total of all radiation from all pixels in the spectrometer slit. The reduced spectra have dozens of apertures that can be lined up to form a single line of pixels for each spectrum . Multiple spectra can be stacked next t o each other to create a 3-dimensional "cube" of spatial coordinates in (1) the slit direction, (2) the scan direction and (3) the wavelength direction. Software has been created to automatically reduce spectra and line them up. Another program was created to allow a user to look at the map of the flux at differen t wavelengths and to provide and view the geometric information for each pixel. The challenge has been to create a format for the latter so the end user working on analysis of these spectral maps can avoid reducing the data each time. Regional Properties That Determine the Formation of Linear Gullies Vicente Ochoa, Arizona State University Mentor: Serina Diniega Linear gullies are long/narrow grooves that are found on Martian sand dunes. Observations of when linear gullies appear shows that they are formed by a combination of winter deposition of CO2 frost/ice and spring sublimation of that ice. Linear gullies tend to form on south facing slopes located in the southern mid -latitudes. In order to b etter understand why linear gullies form in certain regions, I mapped several study sites to find similarities and differences between those locations that have linear gullies and others that do not. Additionally, I determined the physical properties of the region using the images that were taken (by the High- Resolution Imaging Science Experiment/HiRISE) in the southern winter and spring. I found that linear gullies formed in areas that retain CO2 frost for a longer period of time than the rest of the dune slope; some areas even ret ained frost until early spring. I also found that linear gullies tend to face the same direction within the same dune field. These results lead to questions about how frost is retained for a longer period of time in some sand dune s than other dunes, and how that accumulated frost yields the linear gully activity. Characterizing the Mineralogy of Martian Layered Deposits Ethan Putnam 1,2 Mentor: Abigail Fraeman1 1Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology 2Dartmouth University The Martian geologic record, especially its sedimentary record, contains information about past conditions and how they have changed over time. In particular, mineral assemblages tell what conditions these rocks formed in and what pro cesses have affected them since. The Compact Reconnaissance Imaging Spectrometer for Mars (CRISM) on the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) in its Full Targeted Resolution (FRT) mode measures 544 bands from .37 to 3.92 µm over 18 m pixels, allowing for deta iled mineralogical study of relatively small features such as exposed sedimentary rocks. While previous studies have looked at the global distribution of different minerals in all geologic contexts or focused on detailed study of a specific location, this study attempts to fill a missing middle area of research. Determining what minerals are contained in and thus what conditions the Martian sedimentary record formed in and experienced prior to formation. The focus on layered/sedimentary deposi ts allows for a focus on likely sub-aerial and sub -aqueous conditions. We conclude that layered deposits contain surprisingly diverse assmblages of minerals, though most of this diversity is constrained to the Valles Marineris and Meridiani regions. Phyllosilicate -bearing layers are distributed globally. Hematite was found to be surprisingly rare among the studied locations. Proteomic Analysis of Highly UV Resistant Bacillus pumilus SAFR -032 and Antimicrobial Singh NASA's missions to extra terrestrial environments may require the development of advanced technologies to ensure there is no contamination from terrestrial microorganisms. The microorganisms in the JPL Spacecraft Assembly Facility have been extensively documented, with a special focus on SAFR -032, a highly resistant Bacillus pumilus strain. Through our analys is of the strain at the proteomic level, we can understand how exposure to novel, high- stress environments can induce a change in protein structure , leading to the survival of certain bacterial spores even after standard sterilization procedures and spacef light. Once on the International Space Station (ISS), these strains can gain new resistance mechanisms through lateral gene transfer and evolve into resilient strains that may pose a danger to other planets, spacecraft hardware, and life detection missions . We have compiled a comprehensive review of these resistant organisms and created a predictive model of diagnostic peptides that can be used to identify these strains at lower abundance levels than the current genomic approach. Hopefully, these can be use d to supplement the growing microbial database, identify and eliminate contaminant strains, and improve our understanding of how these microorganisms have acquired this unique resistance. 136 Automation of Image Acquisition and Integration for Geobiology Alden B. Rogers (California Institute of Technology) Mentors: Kenneth H. Williford (Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology), Michael L. Tuite (Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology) Detection of ancient geolo gical biosignatures generally involves an iterative process of identifying candidate features in samples and performing localized analyses on them using additional instruments. A workflow employed at the Astrobiogeochemistry Laboratory (abcLab) at JPL comp rises semi -automated capture of gigapixel image mosaics by an optical microscope followed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive X -ray spectroscopy (EDS) of areas featuring promising morphologies. These data inform selection of targets for further analyses by other instruments. In this project, several software programs were developed to streamline aspects of image acquisition and processing in this workflow. One program automatically detects defects in the optical mosaics and directs the microscope to correct them. Another program semi -automatically registers optical, SEM, and EDS imagery, enabling data exploration and exportation using existing geographic information system (GIS) software. Near -Infrared Ima ging for the Juno Mission Vishnu Santhosh, University of Texas, Austin Mentor: Glenn Orton, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology My overall project is oriented toward supporting the Juno m ission's investigation of Jupiter's dynamics and cloud history, which sheds light on similar processes in other planets in the solar system. There are two parts to this project . The first part involves analysis of near -infrared images from ground -based telescopes, the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) SpeX instrument and Gemini NIRI . A data -reduction code in IDL (called the Data Reduction Manager, DRM) is used to reduce the SpeX images, while a Python script is used to reduce the Gemini NIRI data . The goal with the Gemini data is both the reduce the data and transfer the operations in the Python script into IDL for consistency with the process used to reduce all other data. The second part involves seeing whether longitudinal waves in Jupiter's haze near its North Equatorial Belt (NEB) existed only during periods when the dark part of the NEB expan ded northward, or whether they occurred at other times, as well . It is known that waves were present during expansions of the NEB in December 2000, June 2006, August 2009, August 2012, October 2012, and January 2016. A suite of images acquired over many years is investigated near 2.16 m, which is in the middle of relatively strong CH 4 and H 2 absorption, and sensitive to clouds and haze in Jupiter's upper troposphere , to provide a search waves during other epochs . Planetary Protection: Collection, Identificati on, and Archival of Spacecraft -Derived Microorganisms an d Flight Support Implementation for the Mars 2020 Mission Alexandra Rae Santora Mentor s: Heidi Aronson and Ryan Hendrickson Affiliation: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology The Planetary Protection (PP) discipline's responsibility is to promote responsible exploration of the solar system by preventing forward and backward contamination of Earth and other planetary bodies. PP is actively working to reduce biological contamination of spacecraft through technology development, hardware sampling, and evaluation of the extreme microorganisms that survive the harsh environments present in cleanrooms. Given the nature of the Mars 2020 m ission and its planned collection of Mars regolith samples, stringent PP bioburden requirements require the hardware to be meticulously cleaned and monitored throughout the assembly process. My project included assisting in various stages of the planetary protection implementation process, from direct sampling of hardware to planning for the future aseptic assembly facility. Specifically, my project included sampling, identification and archiving of spores isolated from Mars 2020 components, as well as the creation of a document outlining the aseptic assembly room for the sample cache system, including gowning procedures, emergency protocols, and room maintenance. My project also involved other PP support such as compilation of Mars 2020 Thermal Install biob urden counts. Overall, my project aims to gain a better understanding of the microbial ecology of spacecraft hardware and directly support implementation of Planetary Protection activities. Heat Microbial Reduction of Embedded Bacillus atrophaeus Spores Stephanie Smelyansky, Yale University Mentor: Wayne Schubert, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology The encapsulated bioburden poses a threat to the sterility of space hardware used by NASA. Currently, Heat Microbial Reduction (HMR) is the standard method of eliminating the embedded bioburden. The current NASA HMR protocol is both lengthy and costly, consisting of heating space hardware to approximately 116 for about 75 hours for a 3 -log of microbial reduction (582.64 hours for 4-logs of reduction). Using the heat resistant spore B. atrophaeus , we demonstrated that the actual time necessary to eliminate the encapsulated bioburden is considerably lower. We embedded the spores in epoxy and heated the embedded samples to various te mperatures in a silicon oil bath. Then, the spores were recovered via cryogenic grinding, plated, and the number of colony forming units per gram was obtained. From this, we determined the decimal reduction value (D -value), which is 137 the time it takes to re duce the encapsulated bacterial population by 90%. Preliminary data shows that at 115 , the D -value is approximately four hours, while at 125 , the D -value is approximately seventy minutes. These findings confirm that the current NASA protocol, overestimates the amount of time it takes to eliminate the embedded bioburden under this set of conditions. Upon further verification, these findings support a shorter heating time for the HMR protocol to minimize costs and maximize efficiency. Proof of Concept for a Reusable, Affordable, and Efficient High Altitude Testing Platform Divya Srivastava , Rutgers University Mentor: Adrian Stoica , Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology This project falls under the Innovation to Flight program (i2F), which aims to utilize student interns to create, manufacture, and rapidly test new ideas in flight context. This project aims to combine a functional, reusable balloon flight platform with on -board instruments that can provide researchers with new useable data. The instruments themselves are made to be adaptable to different kinds of test flights to allow for future variation in experimentation. This platform was developed and improved through a series of balloon launches. The first incorporated two payloads and took about 5 weeks to develop. The second balloon had 3 science instruments on it and took less than 4 weeks to develop. The third balloon had 3 science instruments and took about 10 da ys to put together. The overall time decreases with each launch because an established platform has been created and therefore the instruments can essentially just be swapped in and out. A reliable and efficient flight platform and procedure have been deve loped for researchers to be able to utilize to test their instruments in a near -space environment. Data Acquisition and Experimental Characterization of Electric Thruster Plasma Plumes Henry Steiner, Cal ifornia Institute of Technology Mentor: Lee Johnson, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Cal ifornia Institute of Technology Electric thrusters operate by ionizing gas into a plasma, accelerating those ions with an electric field, and then expelling them, generating thrust. This type of propulsion system is very po pular for both earth- orbiting and deep - space missions as it requires far less propellant than chemical rockets and can reach higher speeds over a long period of time. While the ion species composition of the plume can be predicted using plasma plume models , there is a lack of data at the interface between the interaction of the ions within the plume, and the ions with the environment. The composition and properties of the plume from an ion thruster were investigated utilizing two instruments: an ExB probe that allowed differentiation between different ion species and an electrostatic analyzer (ESA) that described the energy distribution of the plume. Prior to data acquisition, the instruments were independently installed in a vacuum chamber on a multi -axis m otion- stage with appropriate feedthroughs, adjustable mounting schemes, and protective carbon shielding. To further characterize and validate the plume and thruster models, the instruments should be used in tandem to understand the ion composition of a par ticular energy at given position and angle downstream of the thruster. Modular Test Platfor m Using a High Altitude Balloon Yvonne Villapudua , Citrus College Mentor: Adrian Stoica , Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology The project aims to have the Innovation to Flight team construct a reliable, reusable, and safe high altitude balloon (HAB) test platform for future technologies. The system wa s designed to accommodate flight payloads varying in shape, size and mass within the same enclosure. The testing platform incorporates circular leg bases that can be attached to the desired payload electronics to secure onto a polystyrene foam payload box. Addi tionally, an Arduino Mega micro controller is combined with a HABduino and spot trackers to provide APRS, GPS, and line of sight tracking of the payload. The combination of a high altitude balloon platform with on- board electronics including sensors for pressure , temperature, acceleration, rate, pitch, roll, and yaw provides a versatile testing platform on a balloon for approximately 90,000 feet in altitude, further testing is still necessary for higher altitudes. Integrating the Community Atmosphere Biosphere Land Exchange Model I nto JPL's Model Farm Audrey Wang, California Institute of Technology Mentors: Joshua B. Fisher and Munish Sikka, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology While Terrestrial Biosphere Models (TBMs) are useful for simulating the ecosystem's response to various conditions, existing TBMs diverge greatly in their predicted outcomes. A starting point for understanding and controlling for the differences in TBM outputs is through Model Intercomparison Projects (MIPs). The goal of this project is to integrate CSIRO's Community Atmosphere Biosphere Land Exchange (CABLE) model into the JPL Model Farm workspace and run- protocol, following the guidelines for The North American Carbon Program Multi -Scale Synthesis and Terrestrial Model Intercomparison Project (MsTMIP). After implementing MsTMIP's spin- up conditions in CABLE's code and formatting MsTMIP prescribed driving data so that it can be inputted into CABLE, CABLE was spun- up following MsTMIP's protocol, and MsTMI P Phase I (1901 -2010) simulations were run on the spun- up model. CABLE outputs from these simulations will contribute to both the research at JPL and MsTMIP. 138 Prototyping for a Vapor -Propelled Segmented Robot Concept to Explore the Methane Lakes of Titan Mengyu Wang Mentor: William West, Jet Propulsion Laboratory , California Institute of Technology Recently, a vapor propelled segmented robot concept was proposed to explore the liquid methane lakes on the surface of Saturn's moon Titan. At the highest leve l, this concept has two key innovative technologies: the first is a vapor propulsion system, and the second is the robot configuration. Most of the work done this summer has centered on this vapor propulsion system. An initial testbed using water in place of liquid methane was built. The results from the testbed demonstrated the feasibility of achieving thrust with such a system, but also revealed significant issues with regards to energy efficiency. While the testbed was built largely with temperature and pressure certified pipe fittings, an effective system would involve developing an insulating spherical pressure vessel with a low material heat capacity. The testbed, however, also demonstrated the effectiveness of a cooling based refill mechanism for the propulsion chambers that eliminates the need for a pump. A second system was also developed for use in a submersible vehicle that serves as a complete prototype for one of the segments for a full eel-bot. This work was carried out at the Jet Propulsion L aboratory of California Institute of Technology under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. An Exploration of Alcove Activity in the Northern Mid Latitude Region on Mars Jacob Widmer, University of Maryland Mentor: Serina Dinieg a, Jet Propulsion Lab, California Institute of Technology For several years, Martian scientists have observed that sand dunes in the North Polar Region are active under current climactic conditions. This geologic activity occurs near the crest of some dunes where sand moves downslope, forming triangular depressions called alcoves. New alcoves appear during the Martian winter, leading to a hypothesis that alcoves form due to interactions between sand and the seasonal CO2 frost/ sublimation cycle. However, n o images can be taken in the region during the autumn (due to the polar hood) or during the winter (due to winter night), so their formation is obscured. To bypass the winter imaging complications, we decided to look for similar activity at lower latitudes . High amounts of alcove activity are most common in dune fields among the North Polar Region yet, little is known about the northern mid latitudes. This work aims to constrain the extent and way in which the martian CO2 cycle impacts alcove formation by s urveying several dune fields in the northern mid latitude (30 N - 65 N) region of the planet. Initial results have yielded alcove activity across multiple dune fields and will refine our understanding of the way in which CO2 modifies the martian surface. The Effect of CO2 Snowfall on Seasonal Alcove Formation in Mars' North Polar Region Philip Wong, University of Southern California Mentor: Serina Diniega, Jet Propulsion Laboratory Images gathered by the HiRISE imager aboard the MRO have observed hourglass shaped mass wasting features which form along the dune brinks in the north polar region of Mars. The upper "triangle" of the features named "alcoves" feed into a deposition apron. Documentation of new alcove emergence from Mars year to Mars year have been completed for the dune field dubbed "Tleilax". Additionally, rough calculations of sediment volume displacement for these alcoves have been undertaken to help contribute to helping calculate sand flux within the region. In total, four Mars Years (29 -33) have been evaluated. Along with similar surveys undertaken on other dune fields independent analysis using data gathered from the MCS was obtained which calculated seasonal CO2 snowf all rates. All of these analyses feed into a larger study focused on documenting and characterizing these specific mass wasting processes involved with sand dunes on Mars. MCS data observed snowfall rates and found one anomalous Mars Year seasonal cycle (M Y 31-32) where there was significantly less snowfall. This coincides with our observation that seasonal cycle having significantly less alcove activity, supporting our hypothesis that snowfall quantity is directly related to the number of forming alcoves. Multi -Agent Simulation and Visualization of Swarms of Robot Boats Helena Wu, Cal ifornia Institute of Technology Mentor: Marc Pomerantz, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology One of JPL's maritime robotics projects is to simulate and visualize a fleet of fast- moving boats known as unmanned surface vehicles (USVs). To improve the existing visualization software (2D/3D browser visualizations), this project aims to develop telemetry visualization which displays USV measurements and da ta plots in real -time. The telemetry visualization is a web application built with NASA's Open MCT (Mission Control Technologies) framework and Python3 backend. Both live telemetry and logged data can be used to generate real -time plots, which can be confi gured to display user -specified categories of data (ex. acceleration, velocity, etc.). The web 139 application also allows the user to see the data in different views, zoom -in or scroll to specific data points, and overlay or compile the plots in a panel. I n the near future, additional features such as color -coded limit lines and a wider variety of plots such as bubble plots and latitude -longitude maps will be implemented. This research was carried out at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, and was sponsored by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Numerical Modeling of Saturn's Normal Modes Xiaohan (Helen) Xue (Cali fornia Institute of Technology) Mentor: A. James Friedson (Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology) The Cassini mission to Saturn has detected density waves in the C and D rings that have been determined to be forced by the normal oscillations of the planet. Comparisons of Saturn's free oscillation frequencies to those of the waves forced in the rings has the potential to reveal new information regarding Saturn's internal structure. To determine whether we can accurately infer Saturn's internal structure from the activity of its rings, we can compare calculated spiral density wav e locations to locations observed by Cassini. To this end, we try to identify the normal modes driving such waves and to find corresponding frequencies. While some of the observed waves have been linked with specific normal modes, others, particularly in the very low frequency region, have been more difficult to pin down. We try to find these low frequency modes first by improving the treatment of the planetary internal structure in the model, and then by improving the algorithm used to search for the norma l mode frequencies, integrating existing parallel determinant finder algorithms into our code for more robust calculations. The first step has allowed us to find some solutions in a previously impassable region and match them to observed waves, and we hope that the second will help show the yet lower frequency solutions, which remain elusive. Supercritical CO2 Extraction, Trapping, and Transport Efficiencies of Unaltered Organic Compounds of Astrobiological Interest Brian Yao Mentors: Bryana Henderson and Fang Zhong Affiliation: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Cal ifornia Institute of Technology The notion of discovering signs of life beyond Earth is one of the most meaningful challenges of space exploration. The greatest difficulty in this challenge is that the research parameters are largely undefined and traditional methods of extraction are difficult to analyze. However, the use of supercritical CO2 may serve as an improved technique for detecting possible biomarkers. While implementation of supercritical CO2 as a solvent is often limited to highly specific applications, its potential as an extraction solvent, in regards to organic compounds on icy worlds, is unprecedented. In general, supercritical fluids have a combination of properties that are excellent fo r extraction applications, including good solvating power, low surface tension, and high diffusivity. Additionally, the use of CO2 is particularly suitable for extracting unaltered organics from icy worlds, as it requires relatively low temperatures and pr essures to operate and does not extract salts, which may hinder analysis. I have tested this technique on various fatty acids and demonstrated successful extraction and trapping methods at concentrations as low as 1 ppm. While the trapping of the larger fr ee fatty acids had been problematic initially, optimizing the methodology has resulted in substantial improvements. Design of a Level Winder for the Cable Management System of the Axel Rover Evan Yu, California Institute of Technology Mentor: Travis Brown, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology The Axel rover uses an internal spooling mechanism to maneuver across extreme terrain and access research sites. A proper tether management system preserves the longevity and versatility of the cable. This project focuses on the design of the level winder component, which guides the cable so that it wraps evenly onto the spool. The level winder uses a self -reversing diamond screw, actuated by a single motor, to ferry a lead that directs the cable between two vertical rollers. Multiple compromises in roller size and support structures were necessary to fit the system within the spooling compartment. A benchtop system, including a custom tether monitor and loading spool, was d esigned and constructed to allow subsequent testing of a prototype of the entire cable management system.
